docs.title: Atomicwork Migration App - Product Requirements Document.pdf
docs.summary: The Atomicwork Migration App enables seamless migration from legacy ITSM platforms to Atomicwork's service management system, ensuring data integrity and minimal disruption during the process.
docs.body:
Atomicwork Migration App - Product Requirements
Document
Executive Summary
The Atomicwork Migration App is a comprehensive solution designed to facilitate seamless migration from legacy ITSM
platforms to Atomicwork's agentic service management platform. This document outlines the complete migration
process, from initial data extraction to final validation, ensuring zero data loss and minimal disruption to business
operations.
1. Project Overview
1.1 Objectives
Enable automated migration of users, groups, tickets, attachments, and notes from legacy ITSM systems to
Atomicwork
Minimize downtime and business disruption during migration
Ensure data integrity and maintain historical relationships
Provide comprehensive audit trails and rollback capabilities
Support both full and delta migration patterns
1.2 Success Criteria
100% data integrity preservation
Zero critical data loss
Migration completion within defined maintenance windows
Successful validation of all migrated entities
Maintain all historical relationships and audit trails
2. Scope and Requirements
2.1 Supported Source Systems
ServiceNow
Jira Service Management
Zendesk
Freshservice
Salesforce Service Cloud
Custom ITSM solutions with REST API support
2.2 Migration Components
1. Users and Authentication
2. Groups and Organizational Structure
3. User-to-Group Mappings
4. Agent Group Invitations
5. Tickets (Incidents, Service Requests, Changes, Problems)
6. Notes and Work Logs
7. Attachments and Files
8. Knowledge Base Articles
9. Asset Relationships
10. Custom Fields and Configurations

3. Technical Architecture
3.1 Core Components
3.1.1 Migration Engine
┌─────────────────┐    ┌─────────────────┐    ┌─────────────────┐
┌─────────────────┐    ┌─────────────────┐    ┌─────────────────┐
│   Source ITSM   │───▶│  Migration Hub  │───▶│   Atomicwork    │
│   Source ITSM   │───▶│  Migration Hub  │───▶│   Atomicwork    │
│    Platform     │    │                 │    │    Platform     │
│    Platform     │    │                 │    │    Platform     │
└─────────────────┘    └─────────────────┘    └─────────────────┘
└─────────────────┘    └─────────────────┘    └─────────────────┘

▼

┌─────────────────┐
┌─────────────────┐
                       
                       
│  Validation &   │
│  Validation &   │
                       
                       
│  Audit Engine   │
│  Audit Engine   │
                       
                       
└─────────────────┘
└─────────────────┘
3.1.2 ETL Pipeline Architecture
Extract Layer: Source system connectors with rate limiting
Transform Layer: Data mapping and validation engine
Load Layer: Atomicwork API integration with batch processing
Monitoring Layer: Real-time progress tracking and error handling

17. Conclusion and Next Steps
17.1 Success Metrics and KPIs
Data Integrity: 100% accuracy in migrated data
Migration Speed: Average of 1000 tickets per hour
Downtime: Less than 4 hours for complete migration
Error Rate: Less than 0.1% failed items
User Satisfaction: 95% positive feedback on migration experience
17.2 Post-Migration Activities
1. Data Validation: Comprehensive verification of migrated data
2. User Training: Training sessions on new Atomicwork platform
3. Process Optimization: Fine-tuning workflows and configurations
4. Performance Monitoring: Ongoing monitoring of system performance
5. Support Transition: Handover to Atomicwork support team
17.3 Future Enhancements
AI-Powered Field Mapping: Automatic field mapping using machine learning
Real-time Sync: Continuous synchronization during migration
Multi-platform Support: Support for additional ITSM platforms
Advanced Analytics: Migration analytics and insights dashboard
Self-Service Migration: Simplified migration wizard for end users
This Product Requirements Document provides a comprehensive framework for developing the Atomicwork Migration
App. The document covers all aspects from initial planning through implementation and ongoing operations, ensuring a
successful migration experience for customers transitioning to the Atomicwork platform.

docs.title: Atomicwork-Workday integration.pdf
docs.summary: Atomicwork integrates with Workday to facilitate seamless time-off requests and HR actions within Slack and Microsoft Teams, enhancing employee experience and streamlining management processes.
docs.body:
Submit time-off requests via a guided flow.
Request time off
Employees today demands real-time answers, self-service, and zero
context switching. Atomicwork’s Workday integration brings AI-
powered HR actions into Slack, Microsoft Teams, and the browser.
Employees can request leave, check PTO, or find org info in the flow
of work, while Workday stays the system of record — no logins, no
guesswork, no delays.
Leave and time-off management
Employees receive instant Slack/Teams notifications when
requests are approved or rejected.
Approval
notifications
Managers can take action directly in Slack/Teams — no login
to Workday required.
Manager
approvals
Instantly  check  available  PTO,  sick  leave,  and  vacation
balances.
View time off
balance
Track current and past leave requests for full transparency.
Check leave
request status
Automate  processes  for  special  leave  types  such  as
maternity/paternity leave with policy checks embedded.
Automate
parental leave
Streamline HR. Empower employees.

People directory & organizational insights
Check upcoming birthdays and work anniversaries to plan
team celebrations.
Celebrate
milestones
View hierarchies, team compositions, and contact
information.
Find team
members
Access your profile information like contact info or
emergency details.
View personal
information
Look up official titles ofcolleagues, for context.
Look up job titles
Understand reporting lines and org structure instantly.
Identify reporting
manager
See where colleagues are based for better coordination and
planning especially for hybrid/in-office work.
Check work
location
Start your day with a single click in Slack/Teams to mark
presence.
Check-in 
Mark end-of-day attendance directly from Slack/Teams.
Check-out
AGENTIC SERVICE MANAGEMENT

How it works
Apply for leave directly from
Slack/Teams with smart forms.
Requests are automatically logged in
Workday and status is tracked.
Send approvals to managers in
Slack/Teams—no app switching
needed.
Employees get real-time updates on
their request status.
Raise time-off requests
Submit bills and receipts from
Slack/Teams to raise a reimbursement.
Auto-create expense reports in
Workday with zero manual entry.
Monitor payout progress anytime by
checking with Atom.
Apply for reimbursement
Look up reporting lines and locations to
coordinate better across hybrid teams.
Access your contact and emergency
details directly from Slack/Teams.
Track birthdays, work anniversaries and
celebrate milestones.
Find employee information

docs.title: call-transcript--AtomicEdge_ Enablement sessions.txt
docs.summary: The AtomicEdge enablement session focuses on the integration of the JSM bridge with Atomicwork, enhancing the employee experience while streamlining change management processes.
docs.body:
AtomicEdge: Enablement sessions

Aparna Chugh
Recorded on Oct 8, 2025 via Microsoft Teams, 39m



Participants

Atomicwork
Aparna Chugh
Krishna Pramodh
Sumeet Kumar
Nishant Jain
Riya Sebastian
Vandana R
Raghav Viswanathan, Solution Engineering
Eric Edmonds, Head of Sales
Ken Kaufman, Enterprise Solution Engineer
Paige Wunderlich
Abdul Rahman
Abisanthosh KS
Aishwarya Hariharan
Akshay Kulkarni
Alex Tran, Enterprise Solution Engineer
Bob Weick
Helen Shanthi
Ida Samuel
Justin Cooper
Muthu Kumar
Siddharth Maheshwari

Other
Fireflies.Ai Notetaker Tanvee



Transcript

0:00 | Raghav
do you know if it's going to be a boy or a girl? So we will have a little two and a half year old boy and a newborn baby girl. We got one of each now that's awesome. Congrats. Thank you. We're super excited. 

0:24 | Riya
So, I think we've got most of the team here. We can probably get started. 

0:36 | Riya
I'm not sure if Alex is joining us or Raghav, they haven't. 

0:45 | Krishna
I can pick them. 

0:47 | Riya
We. 

0:48 | Raghav
can probably get started with two minutes in. 

0:51 | Riya
Yeah, it's fine. I'll just start. Okay? 

0:54 | Krishna
Thank. 

0:56 | Riya
you Vandana. Okay. So getting started, the agenda for today is the jsm bridge with atomicwork. We're going to have KP run us through what that is going to look like in the product, and then we can take questions and, you know, dig from there… over to you KP whenever you're ready. 

1:24 | Krishna
Thank you, Ria. Hey, everybody. Can you hear me okay? 

1:28 | Riya
Yeah, awesome. 

1:31 | Krishna
Yeah. So today we'll demo a couple of flows with the jsm bridge. So we're still working on polishing the experience, you know, the UX, the copy, a few things like that. So, you know, we can show the entire admin flow is ready. So I'll be demoing that and I'll also walk you guys through the mocks for the requester experience, right? What the end user experience, employee experience is going to be like, right? But before I start sharing my screen just to touch upon the why kind of revisit why we're doing this in the first place. So as you all know, our product strategy kind of pivoted to enable our gdm teams to sell faster, right? So the gdm velocity going up is a big priority for us. So how are we doing that with the jsm bridge? The idea is to essentially say, hey, don't worry about your change management being, very, effort intensive and at the same time, with high costs, right? We are going in with a strategy where we're saying, hey, we'll coexist with your current itsm stack right now. We're talking about jsm. But of course, we want to build out these kind of bridges with most of our competitors like ServiceNow freshservice as well. So what we're essentially saying is, hey, we will coexist with your itsm stack. It's going to be business as usual for your agents in jsm. For example, while you just take care of your knowledge management, things like that and allow atom to kind of handle your employee experience, end to end, right? And with that, some of the use cases that we've kind of solved with the first card itself. Is we really optimized it for the employee for the first card. So, which basically means employees will be able to go ask knowledge queries, raise report, incidents, raise service requests, also funnel notifications via atom as well. So that everybody's in the loop, the employees are not missing out on something important. And at the same time, you'll also be able to go in and ask atom for let's say a summary of requests that you've raised, right? So with that being said, I'm just going to quickly share my screen, let me know if you can see it. 

4:09 | Krishna
Yep. Can you see my screen? 

4:16 | Krishna
Yeah, we can see it. Yep. All right. So I'm just going to jump in to the app store. So you'll see that we've got the Jira service management app right here. So the installation is, very straightforward. All that we essentially need is your jsm URL and if you have admin privileges with jsm, you're good to go, right? You just need to essentially choose your jsm site, enter the URL and that's basically it. So as soon as you land here, you'll be able to see who connected it when it was connected, the URL that it's linked to how many linked projects you currently have. And when you click on the manage settings here, basically what we display is any sort of atomicwork workspace that you've linked with a jsm project, right? So we can go ahead and link more projects with our workspaces as well. So we're going to give you a quick brief on what you can expect once you have a linking between an atomicwork workspace and a jsm project. So I click on get started. I can choose any one of my atomicwork workspaces. So let's say IP and I can link it to any of my jsm projects as well. So I can choose IP here. And once I hit link… okay… there we go… and you'll see it. So now within my atomicwork it workspace, you'll see that I can access my users here. I have my knowledge. So bringing in all my knowledge information just to make sure that atom is able to handle any sort of query on the knowledge front, all of that is possible from my workspace here. You can also see that there's an indication that this specific atomicwork workspace is linked with a jsm project. And another very important part of this journey is the catalog setting. So essentially, what we're doing is we're able to fetch all of the forms within jsm, right? So that when an employee comes in, interacts with atom, asks a question that let's say has to be an incident or a service request. We're basically fetching all this data from the jsm instance, right? So we're able to actually expose this as a setting as well where we're saying, hey, can we go ahead and create service requests? Can we go ahead and report incidents? Admins have the ability to toggle this on or off? Another thing that is not currently here. But another setting that we have is essentially for admins to come in and tell us what their default form needs to be. So. In the event that an employee asks a question, requests a service or tries to report an incident and the intent is not really matching any of the forms that we have from the jsm side, we will just surface the default form so that there is no hindrance to the creation process, right? Another thing is here, we're making some changes to the sync. So any sort of changes that let's say an admin makes on the jsm side, this includes updates to their service items. This includes updates to let's say adding another service item, all of that we're able to fetch automatically, but we're still giving them the option to kind of manually sync data as well. And once you do sync, you'll basically have information on who made you know, who synced it and when it kind of happened, right? So, all of these settings are housed within the catalog settings. And once you're good to go. So this is basically what you can do from an admin standpoint, and from a requester standpoint, we wanted to keep it, very similar to, you know, what we currently have with atom. We've not really changed the experience that much. There's one main change that I'll talk about, but let's say from a creation standpoint, you… can see that it's very straightforward, right? I come in, I say, hey, I want, let's say access to GitHub or I need a new laptop. 

8:26 | Aparna
Can we pause before we do the end user experience for any questions? 

8:35 | Krishna
Any questions guys so far? 

8:37 | Aparna
Just to summarize right, what we saw is that one workspace was connected to a GSM project, which means that there can be other workspaces in atomicwork that can be fully set up and used within atomicwork. So, for example, HR can completely onboard and set up ticketing workflows, all of it in atomicwork. But we connected it to GSM. So it teams can continue to stay in atomicwork. What we've done here is that this is very bare, right? We've essentially gotten rid of all the settings in admin that are related to… GSM or ticketing, because if the tickets are going into GSM, that's where all the settings will be all your workflows, your SLA, everything is going to be in GSM. What you need to set up here. If you're an it admin is anything that powers atom, right? Obviously, you need to bring in users because you might want admins and agents who are managing let's say this workspace for analytics on atom. The other thing you want to set up is knowledge, right? So because atom directly consumes knowledge from atomicwork and serves it to the user, you'll still come here and connect notion confluence, whatever Google drive right here. Now, in the future, once we launch these agents like iga jml and other agents that again atom will work with, those will also be available here. So anything that atom directly serves will be set up in atomicwork. But everything that is ticket related will be set up in GSM, right? So for admins, that's going to be the behavior. 

10:20 | Eric
So, so when somebody asks, like, so when we think about the setup, like let's just say an entire org was going to come over. Just an it team was going to use atomicwork alongside GSM as far as setup, those are the only things you don't need to set up workflows inside atomicwork. You don't need to okay that's. Actually really good to know because I don't think the sales team was under that impression. We thought you kind of had to build everything for the flow in. So that's really good. Literally, all you need to do is add your users. So when we think about a, and we don't need an exact answer on this. But like Vandana, it'd be good to understand. Like when we start talking about like onboarding somebody, in this case, what does that look like? It should be fairly straightforward. When we think about both cost time effort from the team. It'd be good to be able to speak to that. 

11:15 | Vandana
Yeah, no, definitely. I have some. Can we click on the catalog settings? Like what are you supposed to set up here from a catalog perspective? Yeah. 

11:27 | Aparna
Sure. All again, right? Catalog items are essentially tied to tickets, right? So, these are forms that are set up in GSM. All we are saying is, hey, we are syncing your forms so that atom can serve them, right? So, if you've set up like we've been troubleshooting and, you know, a laptop request in GSM as service request, we are going to sync them, but it's just a toggle so that we can serve it to atom. 

11:53 | Vandana
Yeah, that makes sense. So, how would this work with like let's say that they already have GSM with moveworks set up already. So, how would it work if there is like atom sitting at the same time? They would have to turn off moveworks right? Before? 

12:09 | Aparna
They could? Yeah, moveworks and atom together. Don't make sense? 

12:13 | Vandana
Don't make sense? No, it doesn't make sense. I agree. 

12:15 | Aparna
We'd be the moveworks replacement, in that case. 

12:19 | Vandana
Correct. But they would have to do that before we say that, you know, like that would be the play if there is an equivalent of moveworks sitting out there. 

12:29 | Aparna
Yeah, but honestly, that's not what we are seeing in the market at all, right? Whoever's on moveworks is, okay. Happy. We are seeing a lot of interest in atom, but they want to continue to use GSM. That's what we are seeing. They don't have an equivalent today, like they don't have an isera or a moveworks? 

12:48 | Vandana
Okay. That's perfect. And then on the platform side. So like nothing else needs to be configured from our side, we'll just start using atom. It goes to them. It's like E, bonded up to their side and that's it. Yeah. 

13:06 | Aparna
So this part we can't show because it's not complete from development point of view, but KP was going to show with marks. But if you look at what users do with atom today, right? Number one is I'll ask questions and knowledge is served. So that you just set that up right here, two is I create a ticket, right? Or I create a service request that will get served in atom, but the ticket will actually get created in Jira service management. I know ashwarya has asked a question about notifications. We still want atom to be that one point of experience for end users, which means even though the ticket is in GSM, the end user shouldn't care. Any replies that agents add in GSM, any notifications from GSM, we will funnel back through atom on the same thread. 

14:03 | Vandana
I think there are three questions on the thing. 

14:06 | Aparna
Yeah, Paige, so analytics, we will see we own everything related to conversations, essentially, right? So once we bring these insights and any conversation related analytics, they will just, they will be in atomicwork. All ticket related analytics will be in GSM because that's where the tickets are. 

14:25 | Paige
Okay. So just to make sure that I understand, so we will have analytics as it relates to the conversations that are happening with atom on slack or teams that will all still exist in the tool. 

14:41 | Aparna
Yes, there are two things that are coming that will be relevant to kind of complete the story. One is a list of conversations. So all of these conversations that people are having with atom, there is no way there's no place in the platform you can look at today to see all those conversations. So a conversations list is coming which is kind of like the request list page, but it's just the conversation between user and atom. And the second thing that's coming that you might have seen is the insight space. 

15:12 | Paige
Yep. Okay. Perfect. Thank you. 

15:17 | Aparna
Sorry, Ken, and Sumit, you guys want to go. 

15:21 | Sumeet
Go ahead, Ken? 

15:23 | Ken
Yeah, I was curious about some of the context and how it relates like if somebody's storing all of their assets in Jira, is atom going to be able to pull that context and understand like what might be assigned to a user and some of those details. 

15:40 | Aparna
So, we are not doing a sync of assets from Jira into atomicwork today. And the reason we made that decision was because a lot of people don't want assets to be in Jira and their asset management module is really weak. So users knowledge, assets integrations, we still want them to be in atomicwork. 

16:02 | Ken
Okay. Got it. Thank you. 

16:06 | Aparna
If that changes, we can figure like an enhancement technically that's not the hard part, but we want that context to be with us whether we get them to connect kanji intune directly into atomicwork or fetch it from jsm. That second part, we said let's hold off and see how people really want to do it. 

16:26 | Ken
Yeah, it makes sense. And I was just asking out of curiosity, it's something I've heard. But if I do hear anything different on those lines, I'll reach out. 

16:36 | Aparna
Sure. Thank you. 

16:38 | Sumeet
Aparna part of my question is already answered, came up with another one. If a customer has some knowledge base in Jira service management, plus now we have knowledge bases, we can connect independently to how will that play out? Do they have to migrate their knowledge bases out of Jira service management or we can connect to both external knowledge bases as well as knowledge base of whatever resides in Jira service management? 

17:10 | Aparna
So, customers on atlassian for me, use confluence for knowledge management. Confluence is their knowledge management which we already have an integration with. So they'll have to integrate their confluence to atomicwork. I see they don't have to disconnect it from jsm. I mean, if that integration is native, it's just part of their platform, but they have to connect their confluence to atomicwork. 

17:37 | Sumeet
Got you. So there's nothing outside of confluence which they have in terms of knowledge base, everything resides in confluence. 

17:43 | Aparna
Yeah. I mean if they're using Google drive also, that's different, but as far as atlassian is concerned, it's confluence. 

17:51 | Sumeet
Thank you. 

17:56 | Nishant
Right. I had one question. Not sure if we have already covered it in terms of the channels. I understand we will be supporting all the channels like slack ms teams as well as uag. 

18:09 | Aparna
Yeah, none of that changes. This is still atomicwork. 

18:15 | Nishant
Got it. Okay. 

18:23 | Aparna
Yeah. Nandana. 

18:25 | Vandana
So, in terms of the expected permissions, are we keeping it to the least permissions? We need to connect with jsm. Because that will come up again as an issue with enterprises, yeah. 

18:39 | Krishna
I can answer that. So Nandana I think see there's just two big issues pieces, right? With the permissions part. So one obviously when you're integrating jsm with atomicwork, you'll need admin privileges that's one. But from the kind of information we're fetching from jsm, right? Especially pertaining to users. So there's two parts to this. So one, because of GDPR compliance, what jsm has basically done is they've made access to email addresses for each of their users slightly harder to fetch, right? Because initially it was available. But now what they've done is unless you have your user's consent, you can't really use their email address, right? So that was one. Now we need that email address essentially to fetch their user id, right? So that, you know, we can have the request mapped to the right person and all of that stuff. Now that's one, another thing is for us to basically impersonate a user, right? So if I'm replying, if I'm adding a comment on like this example right here, right? If I'm going in and adding a comment and I'm trying to reply to let's say a request, I've created another thing is now for this response, you can see Priya here has replied. But for this response to be tagged against Priya in the jsm ticket, we basically need to impersonate Priya, right? So it doesn't say atomicwork or atom. It just says Priya right? So for that also we'll basically need to get consent. So we're handling both of this in one shot. So what basically happens is the first time I go ahead and raise a request, we basically prompt them to log in. And once they log in, we'll basically show that, hey, we, you know, we need access to your email address. And at the same time, we're basically trying to do this too, so that we're able to use your user id when we create the request and map your replies to it, right? So it'll be done just once. And once they give us consent, it's done. They'll never have to do it again. When there is another request or reply. 

20:49 | Sumeet
KP, a question on analytics. If I'm an it agent or an it admin, and I have to look at analytics, I have to look at atomicwork platform for analytics and insights into conversations. And then for anything related to ticketing, I have to log into Jira service management, and I have to look at analytics there. So it's like a distributed view because there is no common platform unless they take everything into a Power BI or tableau, and they build custom dashboards. There, you are logging into two interfaces and that's a problem we cannot solve and that's the reality of it, right? Just thinking from a, you know, admin or agent perspective, you have to log into two systems to be able to see the overall picture, correct? 

21:37 | Krishna
Yeah. As I said, yes, but. 

21:41 | Aparna
Go on, KP. Sorry, no. 

21:43 | Krishna
I was just going to say, but see the idea is at some point they will cut over, right? So this problem only exists until, you know, we coexist with them. But ideally, yes, right now, conversations will be in atomicwork and their ticket related data will be in jsm, until they cut over. 

22:01 | Sumeet
So in terms of like a pattern, let's say you have set up some controls for detection of a major incident, it still works exactly the same like it does today, that… agentic atom is able to see a pattern. And then now, instead of opening a major incident in atomicwork, it's. 

22:24 | Aparna
we have nothing to do with tickets, right? Major incident and incidents are tickets. That is an AI capability that looks for patterns within incidents. So all of that is the way to think about this is that we are letting them deploy atom for employees, right? For knowledge for agents and to create tickets, right? It's just that those tickets are in another system. Even the optimization that we've done is for end users, which is where the end user experience has to be seamless when we are saying that they shouldn't care or know that there is another underlying platform but we cannot optimize for agents and for admin, especially, right? And we don't have to like even if someone uses moveworks and jsm, they're using two systems, right? If they're using isera and ServiceNow, they're using two systems so that we can't optimize for. 

23:20 | Sumeet
Understood. Aparna, I was just thinking, you know, since now these things are happening in two different systems. Even though we can see a pattern that, hey, VPN is slow for 10 people in the office who are in the same building on the same floor. We can't do anything. There is no way for us to say, hey, Jira, looks like there is a pattern you should open a, you know, connect these five virtual tickets to a major incident. We are not bothered with, that we will not do. Yeah. 

23:48 | Aparna
There is, we can do it, Sumit, honestly, but we also want to not do it because we have to create that friction or not. We don't have to create friction but we have to give them enough reasons to move to atomicwork. If we solve all their problems even on service management and let them stick to jsm, then there is really no reason for them to move to us at all, right? So. 

24:12 | Sumeet
You're thinking exactly like I was thinking that's where I was going. So, yeah, that's a reason to drive them to atomicwork. That's the reason I was asking. But yeah, thank you for clarifying my mind. I appreciate it. Sure. 

24:27 | Nishant
Just a quick follow up question to what Sumit asked earlier on the analytics. I know you might be having some other things to cover during this call. So just one clarification on this when it comes, if one is using Power BI, I believe that they can still use Power BI as the single source of work when it comes to the entire reporting from atomicwork as well as jsm, that can serve as a one stop shop for all analytics. Is that so? 

25:00 | Aparna
So, today, the Power BI integration only has ticket data. We don't push conversation related data. We do plan to enhance it so that it also has conversation data in that world. Yes, you can bring conversation data from atomicwork, ticket, data from jsm, and create any kind of dashboards. 

25:21 | Nishant
Got it. Thanks. 

25:29 | Krishna
Thank you. From a requester standpoint. Yeah, nothing much changes like Aparna mentioned, you can see that, you know, the notifications are funneling, we've just got an icon to kind of show you where this is happening, right? So the request is created in jsm. And apart from that, when you go through your jsm ticket, nothing really changes for the agents business is usual for them, they'll get all the contacts that we have, all the comments, everything. And yeah, they'll work on the ticket in jsm. Like they do today, nothing really changes in their world. 

26:08 | Krishna
Yep. That's pretty much what we wanted to cover. You can take some questions, any thoughts suggestions? 

26:22 | Nishant
I guess one question is from the positioning perspective, if one is considering both like moveworks, I said, and atomicwork, what are our winning points from the product standpoint? 

26:40 | Krishna
Sorry, Ng, can you say that again?

From our positioning perspective, I was just curious, you know, I've not seen moveworks and SRL coming much into row deals. So that's why you might have to educate me there. But if a prospect is considering moveworks and let's say atomicwork, what are those areas from the product perspective where atomicwork shines over moveworks apart from potentially cost. 

27:12 | Krishna
Yeah. I think some of the cases are similar in terms of they can also create a request, things like that, right? But I think a few things off the top of my head, one is see atom itself, the agent atom's power, I think is one thing that should be highlighted for sure. Now, apart from that, see, these guys don't really have a platform that ties to the experience, right? So in our case, that is also something that is there, you will have a conversation list and there is in time when they cut over to atomicwork, all of that, you have an itsm stack that's already out there, right? So apart from this, you also have atom's key aspects, right? In terms of reflection, all of the stuff that we pitch today to our customers, right? None of that really changes right now. The only, I think main differences in terms of the number of use cases we're solving when it's linked is the use cases that I mentioned, but that also covers the end to end lifecycle for a requester, which is, hey, I have a knowledge query, got it answered. And at the same time a creative request I'm notified where we have covered their entire lifecycle, right? But in terms of differentiation, it's atom's differentiation that you talk about today on your calls that wouldn't really change. 

28:33 | Vandana
KP. I think the question was against moveworks, right? So atom is not really differentiated against moveworks. I think the key differentiation is that we are a single platform to do all of service management in addition, right? That would be the key differentiation. 

28:48 | Aparna
Yeah. And we are not even positioning against moveworks, right? I think this is something we covered before. Also, we don't want to permanently be in this dual stack position. We are saying that this is just an entry point and we still want to move the customer entirely over to atomicwork. So our pitch is still full stack. 

29:13 | Nishant
Agreed. Actually, I was just curious to know from that perspective that from what I gathered probably in any deals, we are seeing more where people want to stick with GSM but they just want to improve the end user experience. So in that scenario, while from our perspective, it would make sense to think behind the scenes that, yes, we would be eventually offering a full stack integrated solution to prospects. But from their perspective, they just probably just be seeing an experience layer which moveworks and other platforms can also provide. So my question was slightly directed from that perspective that how we should be positioning at that particular stage when we don't have that full stack story to narrate. 

30:05 | Aparna
got it. See at a high level. I'm not going to say that there are capabilities that we have on atom that moveworks cannot do, right? I think they can do more than what we have including ign, including your password reset, a lot more integration. So it will definitely take us time to catch up on that front. So we'll have to continue to push the full stack story saying that, hey, when you completely cut over, this is just the one platform you have to deal with as opposed to with moveworks. See a lot of customers are unhappy with moveworks because every integration like this is brittle. Any API integration between a moveworks and a ServiceNow, moveworks and a GSM is not seamless, right? So for that seamless experience that you want… atomicwork, is that full stack solution? So you still have to sell that you're never selling just atom. 

31:12 | Nishant
Okay. Got it. 

31:15 | Aparna
So one question we had for you guys was also that like this is closer to this is close to completion. What do we need to provide from an enablement point of view for you? Rhea, did you want to take that? 

31:32 | Riya
Sure. But before that, I think Alex had a question around comparison with GSM's virtual agent plus atlassian intelligence differentiators. And what should we talk about in comparison? Do you want me to cover that or? 

31:50 | Aparna
We can, or should we, I was thinking that's also one theme I'm seeing is how do we compare against moveworks? GSM? The AI intelligence piece, maybe we take that as part of the response we need to come back with? 

32:13 | Riya
Yeah. Okay. So to set some context here, like Aparna said, this will go live soon and we want to understand in terms of collateral or questions or content that you will need to talk to prospects or what can we provide to enable you? All? Like what would be like Aparna said, we've noted that clearly differentiators and comparisons to our competitors, we will get that in place. What else do you think? 

32:56 | Nishant
Well, if I share it from my perspective, rhea, I guess what you have been doing until now, that would definitely help in terms of having all the faqs addressed in a document, a written material is always better and helps in refreshing the same thing after some time. Also beyond that, just from the positioning perspective, if we can get some sort of a snippet in terms of how we should be positioning, how we should be talking about this potential way. If there are any best practices there, that short writer would also help… just to make sure that things don't get lost in the translation. 

33:41 | Riya
Okay. No bid. 

33:46 | Raghav
I'm just going to quickly chime in here. I know the action item is to list how we compare with other tools that are out there. I think that's the most critical for us to understand as a sales team, how we compare, how we position ourselves is kind of predicated on understanding how our competition does it given that there are multiple incumbents in the space. So I think that is an important asset for us to have two, the faqs that Nishant talked about. And three would be any updated market texture diagram or visual that we can use as slideware that can talk about how the jsm bridge works and what the advantages are like maybe two slides that we can use, I think would be helpful. 

34:34 | Riya
Noted Raghav, we do have some of this in place already, but yes, we do plan to provide additional slides that you can use to talk through this, including a diagram. 

34:52 | Sumeet
Thank you… Aparna, KP. One quick question. I know the same framework and approach can be applied to build a bridge with a service now, or let's say, you know, in the future with another itsm tool, if we come like how does this work now fast track any of those bridges or is it going to be a similar timeframe of couple of months to build the bridges with let's say ServiceNow or any other… itsm tool, assuming there is good demand, not saying, let's do it for one customer, but just a theoretical question. 

35:27 | Aparna
Yeah, I think it could be shorter. Sorry, go ahead. KP. 

35:31 | Krishna
Yeah, I was going to say the same thing. It should be shorter, Sumit. And the reason for that being see the baseline architecture on how we're planning to fetch store data on our end, fetch it, serve that form, right? All of these underlying constructs will not really change with, you know, another player that we want to target, right? So the base underlying architecture will remain the same. It's only a question of, you know, looking at the API documentation and trying to figure out how much we can access stuff like that, right? But yeah, underlying architecture will not change, which means lesser unknowns for us. So it should be a lot faster. 

36:12 | Sumeet
Thank you. I put another question in the chat but, you know, I was curious and that's also a question which people will say, how long does it take to set up? If you're only talking it service management where, you know, the ticketing and change management, everything is in Jira and the agentic atom user experience is some atomic work because previously we were saying here we can make you live in six weeks, on average, six to eight weeks and maybe shorter also depending upon the scope. So I know it's a very generic question. But assuming here you have to connect to 10 knowledge bases. You have to set this up with Jira service management, basic stuff. Maybe some scenario, what are we talking about? Just one part? 

37:00 | Aparna
See Sumit, we say six weeks, but even that number today is very varied, right across our entire customer base. You can be as fast as the team wants to be, as slow as that team wants to be. Depending on how they want to do the POC, how much testing they want to do. The setup in itself is not complex as you saw like you really have to just come in and connect your knowledge and integrations. Outside of that. It's just about how deeply you want to test it and what use cases you want to launch with. The second thing which Vandana called out also and is relevant is that, are they only going ahead with one team that is on jsm, or do they want to go ahead and launch with one team that's on jsm, one team with atomicwork in which case the setup will change, right? So there's no like one answer. If you're looking for like one week or two weeks, it can be, it can be two weeks, but it comes down to how quickly they test and want to deploy. 

38:03 | Sumeet
Yeah, no, I understand. Yeah… understood. Yeah, I think there is enough to be able to manage that conversation. Cool. Thank you. 

38:14 | Aparna
Sure. 

38:26 | Aparna
Yeah, I think you're on mute. 

38:28 | Riya
Yeah. Sorry, I just realized I was just saying, okay, if that's if there are no more questions about the feature itself or around, you know, collateral positioning, all of that, I think we can end the session and we will share all these pieces as we put them together. 

38:55 | Aparna
Thank you guys. Thanks for putting. 

38:57 | Krishna
This together. 

38:59 | Sumeet
Thank you. 

39:00 | Riya
Thank you. 

39:01 | Sumeet
Take. 

39:01 | Raghav
care. Bye.

docs.title: call-transcript--Atomicwork _ Endeavor __ Check in.txt
docs.summary: This conversation touches on IT infrastructure, personal experiences during travel, and cultural observations, providing insights relevant to IT leaders.
docs.body:
Atomicwork / Endeavor || Check in

Nishant Jain with Endeavor
Recorded on Aug 19, 2025 via Microsoft Teams, 52m



Participants

Atomicwork
Nishant Jain

Endeavor
Steven Purewall, SVP Global IT & Head of Infrastructure Services



Transcript

0:00 | Steven
hello, Stephen. I was on mute. Sorry, you did… not a problem. How are you? Stephen? Yeah, I'm good kind of semi recovered now from my travels in India. It was interesting. It's been a few years since I've been because of covid and everything, right? So we didn't travel much because none of us were vaccinated and we refused to get vaccinated so they wouldn't let us go anywhere in the UK. If you wasn't vaccinated, you couldn't go to many countries in the UK. So we didn't travel and this is the first year in a few years. And then there's trouble between Pakistan and India, right? You know, punjab is not that far away. So, my in law said no, you're not coming in. We don't want you to get stuck out here if something's happened or something. So, this is the first year in like five years we've been, so, yeah, it was interesting. A lot of power cuts, a lot of rain while I was in punjab, a lot of power cuts and I was expecting put it that way. Have you seen things improving from the earlier times? Yeah. You know what? Every time there's that look, I'll tell you what is improving your fascination with American fast food, right? Everywhere, you look there's a pizza hut, there's a KFC there's, a burger king, there's a domino's they're all over the punjab. Nishant, it's insane. It's the worst thing you could have done for India is take, this, trust me, your fast food here is so much better than the UK, the us fast food because for a vegetarian, I'm a vegetarian. My whole family's vegetarian, right? So, so you go there. Yeah. You also, you go there, you have pretty burgers, you have all the good vegetarian stuff. But let's be realistic here. It's not the healthiest food in the world and it's not something you should be eating regularly, right? So, so that's the sad thing about inheriting the worst parts of western society into India. So, so that's the bad thing, you know, my wife is obviously out there. My daughter's 18. They're buying Indian suits and stuff like that, right? You know, they get them tailored out there. So, so they had to be. So, we traveled, it was crazy travel. It's like seven or eight suitcases, huge suitcases full of clothes because they didn't just buy them for themselves. They bought them for like family back in the UK. So, I hate traveling with my wife and my kids because they make me carry so many suitcases and stuff. So, yeah, but it was good. It was good to see family came through, right? You know, my father in law passed away recently and we haven't been back. You see, that was one of the reasons we went back. Yeah. Hey, you know what? That's life isn't it. Yeah, parents get older, right? So, at some point, especially our ages, right? My age especially in the fifties, you know, the parents are all in their eighties and nineties, right? It's only, it's only a matter of time, right? That's just part of life, right? So, you got to be prepared. You're not getting hot, Stephen. I must say, I'm 50, what was it? 50, three, 54. And I'm I am, you know, what? You're only as young as you feel, right? The mind is young. The body is old, if that makes sense. That's what I'm going to say, you know, dad needs to lose some weight. He's not eating so much rubbish, you know, and it's all true. I remember that time. Yeah. So, yeah. So, so, I, you know, you have a young outlook in the mind, but, you know, what, the biology waits for no person, right? When I'm 90. I can still be thinking I'm young, but I can't go for a run for five Miles. It's not going to be so easy. So, so, yeah, no, right. Look, I want to have a touch base, right? So look there's two, you and halo, itsm, I don't know what, you know about halo itsm, right? Yes. Yeah. I'm saying that you're I can tell, you are the two short listers, right? We like both solutions. We like yours better, but it's double the cost also, right? It's double the cost. And there's that how quickly can we do this and, how much change can we put on users while going through a massive change? Anyway, right? So, if you think about what's happening, right? This is going through, we're setting up a brand new company. We're a brand new it services, brand new office, three six five, brand new finance system, brand new HR system, right? And so we're really impacting the users with all of these changes. It's a question of what's the anticipation of adding more and more changes and managing that user expectations. Right? That's probably where we're most nervous on Nishant right? As well as the fact that you are a little bit more expensive than the other folks, right? So, so, but, you know, pricing can always be negotiated to a certain extent. I was not expecting you to be cheaper Nishant, right? And the reason is most itsms are kind of cloud based and you're paying for a service that's hosted in the cloud. Where here there's a certain amount of agentic AI happening, which has resources. So, I understand that. I mean, even though everybody claims they've got some of that going on in the background, you guys are built around that model. So I was always expecting you guys to be a little bit more expensive, right? So, so that's less of an issue. But I've got to if I'm going to pitch you guys to, I'm, going to know that we've got to a good place from a cost perspective and we're in a really good place for my, how do we de, risk this, right? And how I'm, not sure how we do de, risk this at the moment. Nishant, right? I'm not sure if we said that we're going with you guys and we're going to implement it a jazz brought up and it's good that jazz was in that last call. He brought up a really good. He brought up a really good kind of outlook where he says, do we go traditional itsm using you guys more traditional with some bells and whistles, or do we go the full AI, whole hog atom agent on day one right now? I'm more of a risk taker. I like the second version rather than the first version. My, my concern is this right? Is that say we go, we're going to pick atomic. That's going to be our new itsm platform and we go the first route which is, hey, you know, we'll give them a look and feel of a traditional itsm, you can open up tickets. I think it's hard to move people from that to the new world if that makes sense? People get settled and become comfortable into what they're seeing and change is always hard, right? And so, do you try to enforce change with a safety net on day one by going the atom agent, right? So, how have other folks done this? How have they gone through this process? Nishant, this is fairly new in the marketplace, but you guys are kind of a market leader. Let's be realistic. Here. There's not many people doing what you're doing? And even like I think ServiceNow brought a company recently who are doing some similar right? Because they know we're not going to reinvent our wheel. Let's see if we can kind of integrate somebody else's technology, right? Which, which I think it's always better to do a Greenfield implementation like you have done because I think you have that existing in two worlds when you do the integration with an acquisition, right? I think that's all every acquisition I've overcome across the company has always ended up that way. So, from that perspective, when you've had these, I know you've said something today and I haven't had a chance to look at it, right? So I will look at it in the next day or so. It's a, you know, we've got a few folks who have gone through this journey. How have they gone through this? What approach did they take? Nishant? 

7:57 | Nishant
Sure. So if I gathered it correctly, Stephen obviously, I guess some part of it you highlighted in the previous call also. But essentially, there are two variables with which you're working with first is how to handle this change management, yes. And second is with respect to the budget thing also. 

8:16 | Steven
Yeah, yeah, justify a product that's twice as expensive when the company is setting up from brand new, it's treating itself as I would say, it's treating itself as a startup although it's not right? But the mentality of, the investors is, hey, you know what? We're buying all these companies in essence for us, it's a startup, right? So we don't want to front load a bunch of costs even though I know the owner of the company, right? He's been the owner of endeavor for a long time and he's going to expand, right? He won't treat it as a startup, right? But it's not all of his own money, right? It's the investor's money. You've got to look after investor's money, right? docs.body:

Participants

S because they were worried that they could, they couldn't get back in. 

3:27 | Sasan

I… you know, both of those guys, especially Jordan was taught saying that, it was really good, that he saw that there are lots of companies doing it, and how they're doing it because, they, he hadn't seen any real example of companies, rolling out AI, and so, he resonated with the framework with the data, with the governance, all that kind of stuff that they were talking about. So, he, yeah, and by the way, he really wants to meet with Patrick, because he's interested, in working over there in that, drone company. 

4:50 | Steve
Oh, really? Yeah. Oh, that's funny. So, he, Jordan's looking for a job. 

4:57 | Sasan
As I mentioned, he's, my son's boss, at the, you know, up to now, yeah. 

5:03 | Steve
Right.

Do that in their conference room over there in the east bay?

Chargepoint. They're not in east bay.

Okay. So, then, yeah, get Raghav, to go down to campbell and do a face to face there. And then, you know, Lennon's local too, have Lennon go with him.

docs.title: call-transcript--Eloise __ Tanvee _ Sync
docs.summary: The conversation between Tanvee and Eloise revolves around their backgrounds and experiences in IT and operations, highlighting the cultural nuances of their respective locations while discussing potential collaboration with Atomicwork.
docs.body:

Tanvee Gaikwad with K3 Capital Group
Recorded on Sep 24, 2025 via Microsoft Teams, 45m



Participants

Atomicwork
Tanvee Gaikwad

K3 Capital Group
Eloise Carman



Transcript

perfect. Do you mind if I have the note taker here? Eloise, no, that's fine. That's fine. Brilliant. Well, where are you joining in from Eloise? Is this the UK?

Is that Eloise?

Eloise? Yeah.

And then maybe I can lead on to the conversation for the next half an hour.

Yeah, sure. So I did notice actually a LinkedIn request and I haven't had a chance to respond to it yet. My most recent role before I was made redundant last year for about seven years is I owned the it service desk and operations for barclays globally. And so that looked after approximately 140,000 colleagues. So, a big role, big scope and worked with managed service providers to operate. docs.title: call-transcript--Impossible Foods & Atomicwork POC Workshop
docs.summary: The workshop focused on the ease of use and approval processes within Atomicwork, addressing user concerns regarding impersonation and approval functionalities.
docs.body:
Impossible Foods & Atomicwork POC Workshop

Paige Wunderlich with Impossible Foods
Recorded on Oct 8, 2025 via Zoom, 45m



Participants

Atomicwork
Paige Wunderlich
Alex Tran, Enterprise Solution Engineer

Impossible Foods
Liz Garcia, IT Process Manager

Other
Devin Licon, Sr. Manager, Employee Experience



Transcript

0:10 | Liz
I think the POC is going pretty good. There are some questions obviously… but overall, I think the team kind of likes the ease of it. You know, it's very fair. Things are right there in front of them. They don't have to go through many tabs to look at things… that's been the positive side. Now, I know that you said we can't impersonate people and we can't approve on behalf of other people today. So that's going to be a little bit tricky because sometimes our users don't like to forget to approve. And so then we end up hounding them to, hey, do you approve and then approve on their behalf in the tool. So I'm not sure what workarounds of anything could be there that we could possibly try out?

We did relay the feedback internally. So it is something that we are going to consider. Other customers are asking about it as well.
