34:19 | Alex
Yeah, that would tie in similarly around the upcoming controls that we'll have. So you can imagine some more insights around conversations, how we're thinking about it. Is every conversation will be its own entity because there's going to be plenty of scenarios where conversations don't turn into tickets and there's not going to be reporting or logs around that. So having a more dedicated place to view logs of conversations and be able to provide feedback on those conversations and help train Adam in a particular manner. If those types of prompts come in again. 

34:52 | Devin
Right. Because looking at the analytics for Adam's services, it looks like those are all high level and I don't know if our data just doesn't have it. But do you have the ability to drill down into some of the information? Maybe not the, well, I guess the question would be across them because it's things that are answered by Adam. It would be ticket deflection feedback like the feedback thing. I'm assuming you'd be able to click into the different feedback components and see the user's feedback. But for some of the other items, maybe not unique users requests deflected answered by adams. Would you be able to pull up some of the details for where the system is getting those metrics? 

35:31 | Alex
You would be that's part of the conversation logs essentially that will be tied to these metrics here. So we don't have them native yet, but they're going to be enhancements around what we're calling Adam insights and then other conversational analytics too where you can imagine being able to chat with Adam, but as an administrator supervisor and be able to ask for specific metrics or insights or trends? 

35:52 | Devin
Okay. Great. Yeah, because if we can get down to that level where we can review or we can get Adam to curate components of it and then be able to train directly on responses that would be ideal because then, yeah, I mean, it's a lot more difficult when it's a bit nebulous. And then you're relying on kind of external data to train a system that you have limited input on. 

36:14 | Alex
Right. Yeah, I can double check. I know that one's coming out very soon. 

36:18 | Devin
Okay. 

36:21 | Paige
And I think, that one too, I mean, when Alex says very soon, I think it's set for like either this month or next. And I think that one too is there's a lot of questions or there's kind of this goal behind it of how do we then take? Because it's great to have all those conversations. It's great to have that data around what's been answered or unanswered. But then how do we action that data to make Adam better to make Adam smarter to predict what that context is or what that next question is going to be? And be able to answer questions more effectively? So that's really where we're getting to with having these conversational analytics. It's great to have the data, but it's what do we then do with it? So, our main goal is to really make Adam more effective with the data that we're getting from that, and allow you all to see those gaps and those areas that we might need to improve on to make that deflection rate or that resolution rate from Adam just even higher than it is at the beginning. There's lots to come. I know that… you all, I kind of want to go over and maybe this is on another meeting that we can do almost like as a closeout of the POC, but I very much would love to understand kind of like we were talking about at the beginning with approvals… and that, and… being able to approve for someone else, what gaps you all are seeing that are going to be, a make or break for you potentially going with atomicwork or not. I know that we are coming up on likely, I know that, your, I believe their service now renewal is, end of February, beginning of March. 

38:40 | Liz
Yeah. Somewhere that time, okay? 

38:43 | Paige
So, we're coming up on a time where, if we were to, if you all were to go ahead with atomicwork, with the implementation time as far as getting all of those hundreds of workflows into the system and ensuring that everything is functioning really well, before going live, we would probably want to start to have some of those conversations, because we're just getting a little, not tight on time. Right now, we have time but, I can see, you know, for, the next couple of weeks to get going. And then all of a sudden, we end up being tight on time. So, I would love to understand those. Alex and I can maybe pull together the gaps that we are hearing, and send those over to you. And then if you all can identify for us, the ones that you're like we have to have this for go live. This is absolutely the most, you know, the utmost importance to us or this one is like a nice to have, we would love to have it at some time in the future, but it's not going to make or break us. That would be really helpful for us then to go to our product team and say, these are the ones we really need to focus in on so that we can make that commitment to you all. Should you choose to move forward with us that we will have that available for you for go live? So that's really our goal. And I'm hopeful that we can get to that point so that, we can make this, you know, hopefully a fairly easy decision, but I also want to, you know, be mindful of the fact that, you all are still very much testing. We just want to get ahead of this if we can. 

40:19 | Liz
Yeah, definitely appreciate that. Paige. Yeah, we are going to be looking, you know, the team is still summit testing. We have a facilities team testing the app as well to give us their feedback, cause I mean, they will also be impacted with the, whatever change we decide to go with. And then, yes, we kind of do kind of have like a list of our must haves that we need to have from day one. So we will let you know, yeah. 

40:46 | Paige
Perfect. Okay. That's great. If you already have that list going then, yeah, we can save that or, you know, we can add to it by, from what we've heard. But, would you feel comfortable sharing that list with us, today? Or do you want to wait until the POC is complete for you to, share that? 

41:06 | Liz
Yeah, I kind of see compare it, cause I, we're still kind of going through the data, the feedback that we've received and, where things align. But, yeah. 

41:14 | Paige
Okay. Great. That absolutely makes sense. Then we'll hold tight on that. And once we receive it, we'll then, you know, connect with our product team. Also take some of the feedback that we've heard and add that in there. But that all sounds good. Would you all like to schedule another, session for us to go through or, are you feeling comfortable enough that we could, you know, potentially schedule one next week that would be like, our closeout session where we can go over some of the data that we've gone through? 

41:48 | Liz
Yeah, I think we're at the point where I think we can kind of understand things a little better. We'll continue testing and then we'll just the schedule are like, okay, end of POC, what are our next steps and feedback? 

42:02 | Paige
Okay. Sounds good Devin. 

42:06 | Devin
Okay. Anything you want, Liz, I'm here for you. 

42:10 | Liz
Oh, thanks Devin. 

42:13 | Paige
Good teammate. So, okay. So we'll we can schedule, that next session is being the closeout. And then, I think what would likely be a good next step, is at that closeout, gathering those requirements that are, the must haves, Alex and I can meet with our product team, and then we can come back to you with, almost like a roadmap session of how we're planning to meet those requirements, and what that looks like on the roadmap, and then go from there as far as, you know, whether or not you all feel comfortable, you know, honestly, I don't even know. Are you all, evaluating other tools that, are potential replacements for ServiceNow, that you're working on deciding between? 

43:00 | Liz
Yes. Okay. 

43:01 | Paige
Okay. So then you, at least at that point, we'll have kind of all of, our cards of what we're able to do for you. And then hopefully can make a really informed decision based on what we'll have by the time you would go live. So that works. Okay. Cool. Do we want to go ahead and put that on the calendar? 

43:21 | Liz
Yes, let's go ahead and let's do it. Let's take a look. 

43:28 | Paige
Okay. Here we go. 

43:32 | Devin
Are we looking for next week or two weeks out? I can't. 

43:36 | Paige
next week would be ideal if you all are open to it two weeks out. Both Alex and I are at Gartner it symposium in Orlando. It's going to be, it's going to be a week. So, we would love, for next week if you all are available. 

43:56 | Liz
Okay. It is a short week for us next week because we do have Monday off. So it is nine a. M. Yeah, nine a. M. I think will work… yep. 

44:09 | Paige
Nine a M on, Friday. Great. Good. Yes, thank you. We will go ahead and schedule that. And we will during that meeting, go over, everything we've built out where we're at, understanding some of those requirements. We'll gather together what we have. And then, we will look to schedule that product meeting or I'm sorry, that roadmap session, either that following Friday or potentially the start of that next week once we get back. So, we can figure that out when we get there, but I'll send over that invite and if anything, if you need any help between now and then, please feel free to reach out. 

44:55 | Liz
Will do. 

44:56 | Paige
Okay, wonderful. Thank you. 

44:57 | Liz
Both. Thank you both. Good. Seeing you both. Good to see you. Yeah, hope you have a good week. We'll talk to you soon bye.

docs.title: call-transcript--Jim _ Alex _ Paige - Quick Connect!
docs.summary: The discussion focuses on integrating a ticketing system with Slack to streamline ticket creation and response, facilitating smoother communication for IT operations teams.
docs.body:
Jim / Alex / Paige - Quick Connect!

Paige Wunderlich with Applied Intuition
Recorded on Oct 8, 2025 via Zoom, 24m



Participants

Atomicwork
Paige Wunderlich
Alex Tran, Enterprise Solution Engineer

Other
Jim Tennant, IT Operations Engineer
Benjamin Vertal



Transcript

0:00 | Jim
I can create, you know, I'm being facetious, obviously, but tagging an item to create the ticket is what I was kind of getting at like just the ability because like when you said it depends on how our team uses slack, just picture the most unstructured crazy thing you can. And that's probably how our team uses slack. So it's just pings all over the place. That's one of the reasons why we're looking into a ticketing system that integrates a little bit more smoothly with slack because… we want people to do things how they're kind of used to doing them. But we also still want to make sure that tickets are created so that's good news. The other thing the other question I had related to that then is in atomic and this is something that I actually ran into. So obviously it is the ideal situation where the agents like the it team or whoever is using the backend like portal to triage and resolve tickets and stuff like that. However, there are times where and I would like to encourage that to be the main focus. But there are times when someone's running in and out where you know, you might want to just respond in slack real quick, but you don't want to like DM, you want to make sure that is in the conversation in the ticket with assist. Essentially, it creates like you get a ping and… let me find an example. So, yeah, right here, so it shows me like if I could, can I share my screen real quick? Okay. And it probably is just something I'm doing wrong, but I figured I'll just ask on here. You know, zoom has this big green share button right in the middle and I always still seem to miss it. Okay. So can you see this? Okay. Perfect. Yes. So yeah. So you can see here, like this ticket came in, someone's requesting access to a Jira board. Okay. So like obviously I can click this and it'll take me to the ticket. But this like this conversation thread syncs with the work item. So if I respond here, like I think you remember me asking about like internal notes. Obviously, that functionality is not here yet. That's fine. But regardless if I respond here and hit enter, it's going to go to the ticket and it's going to like the person that put this ticket in is going to see it on their end. Like a conversation. I noticed that when I do that with… I don't know if I'm going to be able to easily find one without going through a bunch of stuff that no one wants to. See… well, let me just put in. Let me put in a test ticket actually. 

3:02 | Jim
Everything's P0. Okay. So this request comes in, this is what I see in slack. Like I, okay, just starting from the top then obviously, like we would prefer from a functionality standpoint that the person working the ticket would do it from here, right? But like let's say they don't… where do I like? Is there a, can I thread this somewhere in slack to where like respond to ticket? Obviously, that's not going to work to where it goes to the ticket, but it's still in slack or no? 

3:38 | Paige
So, I'm almost positive and Alex tell me if I'm wrong, I think that if you reply to that thread as you would normally for. 

3:47 | Alex
Yeah, I'm trying to see the option on your screen but the three dots on the, yeah… if you reply directly to this, that will append to the ticket. 

3:56 | Jim
Because I thought I did that somewhere and it did not do it. But, of course, I'm not going to be able to find that. Oh, this is testing something else. 

4:14 | Alex
Yeah. So, I think any notifications from an assignment, an approval, a private note, an, at mention, all those default notifications that will come in through atom, you can be able to reply directly in that thread, and then that will automatically get appended to the ticket. But if you can find the example where it didn't we're always happy to take a look. 

4:36 | Jim
Oh, okay. It did. Then well, hang on. Let me look in. 

5:03 | Jim
Obviously, this has since been resolved, but. 

5:18 | Jim
This one might just be. 

5:19 | Paige
Might be because it's closed, yeah. 

5:21 | Jim
Yeah, that's fair. Okay. Let's test it from here. Atom, can you create a ticket with? 

5:44 | Jim
Always weird talking about myself in the third person. 

5:51 | Jim
While this is doing its thing because I probably just answered, I think it's just maybe it wasn't as obvious that I, because it doesn't say anywhere. Not that, that's a big deal. But like, I don't think it said somewhere in here, like reply to this thread to, you know, it just didn't seem as obvious to me. So, I guess I just never thought to track it that's okay. That's good feedback, sorry. 

6:12 | Alex
Proactively to let users know. 

6:14 | Jim
Well, I mean, this is just stuff that I guess you assume people should just know. So that was my fault. Yeah, I did. Okay, meh. 

6:26 | Jim
No, no, no slack. Why do I need to share the thread with myself slack? 

6:31 | Paige
It might. 

6:38 | Paige
Yeah. Well, well, I do think that's really good feedback as far as that not being as obvious and us potentially including some sort of a note that says like reply in the thread in order to reply to the ticket or whatever that might be. And I also did want to point out on the atom app from that main, that like home screen, you should see. So like in the assigned to you bucket right there. Yep, perfect. So if you click on that, you'll see all of the tickets that are assigned to you. And if you click on the little ellipses on the right side, you should see yep, a reply there as well. So you could go there if you wanted to too. So that's another helpful place. 

7:29 | Jim
Thank you. Ben. I know I just saw you hop down a little bit ago. I'm adding this to the configuration guide. You should be very proud of me. 

7:39 | Benjamin
Love it. 

7:41 | Paige
Hi Ben. 

7:42 | Jim
You're welcome. I'll get over to you in just a second. Ben. I think you just had one more question. I'm trying to remember what the question was. Thank you. That's exactly what I was looking for, cool. 

7:54 | Alex
I just tagged them in a previous thread which I have some additional screenshots if you can utilize any of those as well for your guide. 

8:00 | Jim
Great. Thank you. What was the other question now? 

8:12 | Jim
And then just, it looks like it, I mean, this is just one of those obvious things, but we should always direct people to every time like Adam responded to me. But then I responded and nothing happened until I tagged it again, right? And that's by design. I didn't continue to tagging it. 

8:26 | Alex
Yeah, that's by design within channels because channels there's so much noise with people communicating back and forth. So it's intentional that you have to at mention Adam within a channel. If people are interacting with Adam as a separate DM in the app, you don't have to at mention Adam at all. 

8:50 | Jim
Okay. So when I'm in a channel… it just, it seems and I think you said this before, the preferred method is just to DM Adam, correct or like just to DM Adam directly. But the, but then he doesn't it doesn't get the context… of the channels unless he's there you go saying he again, it's been added to those channels, right? So like if I wanted to like take one of our like channels… that's been like the beginning of time and add Adam to it so that I can get all that context well for one, is that a good idea? Is that information overload? Should we just start fresh? And two, is that even the recommended thing to do versus a DM? Yeah. 

9:41 | Alex
It is recommended and you can think of it as if there's an existing channel for everyday questions and there is context there where people have answered it in a particular manner. Adam will understand that context and then be able to respond in a similar manner based off of previous conversations within that channel that agents have done in the past. Now that's just one option in addition to the DM. So you both, you have both options and it's probably going to be some of the guidance that we can help with users as well in terms of helping create that guide on best practices and when to use a channel versus when to slack directly to Adam. 

10:20 | Jim
Okay. Yeah. I think that would be good to have any resources for that just to help direct people. And then we can obviously make our own too. Okay? I feel like I had more but Ben, I'm sure you have a few and I don't want to waste your time by inviting you and giving you no chance to talk. So the floor is yours? 

10:40 | Benjamin
Sure. No problem. Hi. 

10:42 | Paige
Hi. 

10:44 | Benjamin
Yeah. My name is Ben. I've been with applied for, I don't know about nine months now, 10 months. I guess for an October… helping with it stuff. I'm not very familiar with Adam. I've had superficial touch on the admin portal and interacting a little bit with the agent. I do have like 50 open tickets right now and a whole bunch of, I spent a little bit of time trying to write up a gemini gem in order to, you know, summarize some of whatever's been happening. But I guess to Jim's point, a lot of discussion and troubleshooting happens in slack directly. It would be great to be able to capture some of that somewhere somehow that isn't you know, again, I lose context waiting for portals to open because requests come in quickly enough and adversely enough that, oh, yeah, I forgot to open that and then you get signed out and you have to sign back in. So one of the things that interests me through Adam is its ability to connect into cloud services to get rid of some of the easier. Like I don't know. I guess an issue we have now is Okta, group access, for example. So a lot of requests that say, I just can't access something. I'm blocked can't work that requires, you know, me to go sign into something and make a change. I think it's relatively simple but just requires that context and a little bit of awareness. And I guess we have the tools available to us and my interest is making sure that they work. I don't want to put too much time into a demo tenant if. 

12:21 | Jim
you. 

12:22 | Benjamin
know like training time and attention will be lost moving into a production one. So that's one thing that I kind of found out when I was talking with Jim… and then doing some more complex stuff. So some of the interests that I do have is we use tailscale and that often also requires or we get a lot of requests there. And if I had a bot that had enough awareness on how to properly ask and frame the question for these changes, that, and then, you know, write the answer for us and just provide that as part of the answer which I've got other agents doing. I just don't know how to connect and do some stuff with atomicwork. So those are some of the, I guess the immediate use cases that I would have that I think the capability is there but I don't really have the time and bandwidth necessarily to help train and figure out and move through, but I do have a lot of examples that I can use to train it. So again, my interest was not training something that would just forget about it after the bat. Yeah, I guess those are quick hits on a little bit of bandwidth I've had on atomicwork. 

13:20 | Paige
Yeah, that's great. And it is totally understandable that, you know, you don't want to invest a ton of time on the POC when production will be different. You're absolutely right. That is by design because if you were to, you know, throw a bunch of random stuff in there that wasn't applicable for production, we want to make sure to save you from that as well. So our goal is really to make sure that the production instance is like ready to go is giving proper answers. Day one, you know, requires a little tuning and we don't want you to be worried about essentially messing it up in the POC. So that absolutely makes sense as to why, but that's our why as well. So for the Okta, portion, Alex, would you mind touching on that part? 

14:12 | Alex
Yeah. I mean the very standard use case for us, you might have noticed that we do already have native integrations with Okta. So being able to help orchestrate some of the provisioning, deprovisioning, password resets, or even be able to tie that to existing onboarding or onboarding processes, use cases that we're already aware that are important for you folks. And then things that we have documented for potential implementation as well. If you're curious about what's to come on the roadmap with, that there's actually some new exciting things we have around identity governance access. You can think of things like time bound access. If someone is on a leave of absence, you need to revoke access via Okta during a certain time period. So we're looking for a lot more enhancements around the Okta ecosystem in general. So more things that come with that. But if there's specific use cases you have in mind that you just need more clarity on, we're happy to maybe mock something or just provide more detail at a high level from a roadmap perspective. 

15:03 | Jim
How does atomicwork… we've thought about that too and something that we are looking to implement more is Okta, identity governance, but it seems like there's a lot of overlap because it looks like atomicwork can essentially do that too along with just in time access, which I think Ben and I are both interested in. But the scary thing is it seems like it'd be incredibly easy to mistype and just grab the wrong person's, name and just say like deactivate and then it just it blows up the wrong person. So like what safeguards are there in place for atomicwork? So that doesn't happen, are there confirmation steps? Like does Adam just go with it? And just, all right, and then just go or what? 

15:47 | Alex
Yeah, good question. There are indeed certain guardrails in place, whether that is a certain policies, certain attributes that we want to check or other confirmation we need before someone actually executes something via Adam, especially if it's something important like access controls for a particular software. 

16:02 | Jim
Okay, perfect. So I guess, I mean, obviously, that's one of those things again that's kind of hard to build out. I mean, we do have a sandbox but for Okta, that we could potentially plug it into. But other than that, it's kind of hard to do it without doing it live. And then the other question I had is I mentioned before plugging this into like Jira, because of like the software projects and stuff that we're like the rest of the Eng teams are moving actually like moving and consolidating into Jira. We currently have like a security slash networking board in Jira, but Ben and I are basically the only ones that are still using it. Everybody else just kind of abandoned it. I would like to get back into people using it for tracking like because obviously you have like incidents and service requests and then you have things that are more like project level items, right? That aren't really service tickets. So to put them in as a service ticket in atomicwork seems a little bit weird. I guess it's not like wrong. You could do it, but we're talking about some of these things are like refresh entire like network for new building like that's. Like an epic. Does atomicwork have a product or something like that we could flip over to like a project board like a separate workspace, and have it be like a kanban board that's like a project board instead of ticketing? Or is it basically just a skin on the same thing? Like do you guys have anything like that? We could just take our entire team out of Jira completely. Yeah. 

17:24 | Alex
So we could have that specific function within its own respective workspace. It would still be the same UI, but you could relabel it something else just because we don't have a native project management module, but you could still have the same function as a ticket but relabel that as a project perhaps as a workaround? 

17:44 | Jim
And then we can change the views and stuff to where it would be more of like a kanban board or something or is it still? Yeah. 

17:48 | Alex
Kanban's not something we do yet, but something I can double check on the roadmap. 

17:52 | Paige
Yeah. I know that we've had a lot of questions around that recently. It's funny how things like that come in waves. So yeah, we definitely owe an answer for a few people on that. So we'll push on that again. 

18:04 | Jim
Okay, Ben, back to you, do you have anything left to ask? 

18:08 | Benjamin
Yeah. Is there a connection with Jira at all? Just even if it's a duplicative effort, we have workflows and things that bring data in through Jira for example, now may create a ticket basically to share that information over and allow then all the agentic stuff to take over. Is that capable? Can we do that we do? 

18:29 | Alex
Indeed. So we'll still have that native integration to Jira. So if there's any things that naturally stay on Jira that you just want to sync or want to escalate from atomicwork to Jira, we can be able to support that as well. 

18:37 | Benjamin
Is that something that we can explore or evaluate now? What does that look like or take? I guess I would just like to, again, I got 50 tickets. I got lots of use cases. I want to see what it can or can't do and I would love to just get some of the stuff turned up and turned on. 

18:52 | Alex
Sure. Let me go ahead and share my screen and we can dig into maybe my instance as an example. So if I were to, so a couple of ways where we can integrate Jira, if I open up an example ticket, let's say if someone's maybe having this issue with Salesforce, we end up having to escalate this to maybe a specific Jira issue or a Jira project. So this is just one of the ways where we can integrate with Jira to be able to sync or escalate from certain things that happen with atomicwork directly in Jira. The other way could be a low. So if you want to trigger something on the back end, if I open up a workflow and be able to open up an action within our workflow automation, anything that can trigger, go through a normal flow or condition triage within our workflow, automation can then execute something directly in Jira as well. So these are just some example functions, but we could do additional ones as well. If there's something else that you had in mind around project issue management or maybe something more unique on the Jira side? 

19:53 | Jim
When you escalate it to a Jira issue. Does it mark the ticket as resolved or does it keep it in sync until the issue is resolved on the Jira side? 

20:01 | Alex
Depends how you want to define those settings, and it also will automatically link to the ticket. So it will reference it in real time? 

20:10 | Jim
And Ben, I think that's one of those things that it's kind of difficult, right? Without plugging into live data. How can we really test this? I mean, I guess we can use our sandbox Jira instance and do it. 

20:24 | Benjamin
Yeah. And that's part of my like we're still strapped on time and attention. It would be great to do all those things. But again, I got to deal with the tickets that I want to burn down and I don't want to again put a bunch of time into the demo workspace. So, you know, I think if it works, it's great. I want to see it, but I don't want to have to put in a bunch of connectors, do a bunch of testing, waste half a day on something that I won't be able to won't, move me towards my goal of getting stuff done. So, I guess I'll take that. 

20:50 | Alex
Documented. We're happy to just take a look, give some initial answers on feedback and also make sure we have that context related to our implementation team or customer success team. So they're aware of what most high value use cases you folks have. 

21:03 | Benjamin
Okay. And I guess one of the other pieces, I mean, there are a lot of integrations. There are a lot of power here. I guess it just takes a lot of time and attention to draft these things together. There might be a couple examples that are built in there, but… yeah, I think we'll just have to figure them out again. I just didn't want to put a bunch of time into stuff that I can't carry forward. So, okay… I think I have two really major questions just have to use it. 

21:31 | Paige
Yeah. And Ben, I think, you know, this being one of our first times that we've talked… we've mentioned pretty heavily on previous calls that our implementation team is not like your standard implementation team that's going to say, hey here's your projects that you need to go complete, have fun. We'll check your work when you're done. They are going to take care of all of that for you. So, I know that you all have a lot of work on your plates and that has been very clear all the way through when we first talked to Patrick about this. Now, you know, in our conversations with Joe and I'm guessing likely will be the same with Graham tomorrow that they have said we do not want for this implementation to impact our current workload. And we do not want our teams to be responsible for additional work to get this in place. And we have very much all the way through said that will not be the case. And I'll tell you the same thing. We do not want to add to your workload. So we will be taking on the bulk of that work to recreate workflows, to set this up to make sure that it is meeting all of your expectations around integrations and workflows related to those integrations. 

22:50 | Benjamin
Cool. Sure sounds great. I think Graham will probably ultimately be the leader on this implementation. That sounds great from a technical side. I think we moved through most of the major problems like getting it to reference some of our internal documentation. So that's good. The better we do there, the smarter the tool is, which is great. And then, you know, that's kind of outside the tool. It'll transfer. Again. That was my focus is where and how much of this attention, how can it be recreated? So that's all good. Cool. I do have to jump to another meeting. Thanks for letting me join in. And I think if there's one tomorrow that'll be a good time to reset. So thank you. 

23:31 | Paige
Wonderful. Thank you all. We appreciate it. 

23:34 | Jim
And just a final note that if Graham gives us the green, like part of the reason why I haven't spent a bunch of time recently putting a bunch of more work into it is because we just shifted over to Graham, right? So like we had gotten kind of a soft like Joe said that Graham said this, but I wanted to see Graham's actual like reaction to it tomorrow, see what he actually has to say because I didn't want to put a bunch of time into it and then him be like, actually we're pivoting, yeah. So if he gives the green light, then I'm more than willing and I'm hoping he lets me drive it and drive the implementation as much as time allows. Yeah. But that's kind of like tomorrow will be a good tell. And Ben, I don't think I'll mind, but I'll just bump him and say like, hey, can I throw Ben on that meeting if he has time? And I'm sure it'll be fine. But if you want, just because I think that you and I are probably, you know, going to be working together a lot on it regardless if I'm taking lead or whatever for this one. So it's up to you. 

24:34 | Benjamin
Cool. All right. Appreciate the time. 

24:36 | Jim
Thanks everyone. 

24:37 | Paige
Thanks, Ben. Thanks, Jim. We'll. 

24:39 | Jim
Talk to you soon. Appreciate your time. 

24:41 | Paige
Yeah, you too. Bye.

I mean, entire organization, enterprise service management as you would call, why we want to be close to the employees. We are continuously adding those knowledge sources. So people don't have to build especially administrators don't have to recreate the same content. docs.title: call-transcript--K3Capital _ Atomicwork _ Demo
docs.summary: This recording features a demonstration of Atomicwork's IT service management capabilities, tailored for a new user at K3 Capital. It includes insights from experienced team members about effective integration with existing tools.
docs.body:
K3Capital : Atomicwork | Demo

Tanvee Gaikwad with K3 Capital Group
Recorded on Oct 1, 2025 via Microsoft Teams, 1h 1m



Participants

Atomicwork
Tanvee Gaikwad
Vijay Shankar

K3 Capital Group
Eloise Carman

hi.

Just as Tanvee mentioned, I come from an itsm background, worked very closely back in the days when we were building freshworks and atomicwork with some veterans in the itsm field. And I will be for veterans, Stuart rams, Stephen Mann, Barclay Ray. These have been some of our consulting partners who worked personally with us in building our platform. So really good to bring out their names because those have been veterans in the itsm world. So, thank you. As Tanvee mentioned, we'll cover the platform. I would love to show you the product end to end but today might not be a very customized demo. It would be very generic based on the generic itsm capabilities. Yeah, if you like what you see, definitely, we could spend like 30 more minutes going a little bit deeper. Ideally, we would want to have an NDA, understand your use cases, better go through a very compliant way. But just to give you a quick glance of atomicwork, we are a modern service management platform. Why we call us a modern because we go away from the archaic way of email portals, kind of an experience. We go heavily with a conversational experience first. So if I were to put it in a simple terms, I know compliance and security aside, think of us like the chat gpt or an AI or a generative AI platform for the organization, by the organization of the organization. What I mean by that is we are built only for that specific work. We have guardrails around the system to not cross the itsm or the esm path. If people are asking about, write me a poem. Can you help me with writing an email or a cover letter? It's strictly out of bounds for the platform. We are very strict to the compliance and the regulations and the policies set by the firm, which is why we are also proud to say that we are iso 42,000 certified, the first AI related certification, that compliance certification that has come up. So we are compliant with that as well. Apart from soc two and so on. I'll give you a quick glimpse of the product today. We take a very multimodal approach. What we mean by that is most organizations today have a lot of confusion on which is the best AI model to go after? Will this AI model help us with solving for a particular need? Because every team has its own requirement in terms of AI marketing and sales, need a lot of research related AI models, it teams need a lot of troubleshooting related AI models, whereas regular employees need a rag which is retrieval augmented generation where they give a question and the system should be able to give them the right answer at the right time instantly without wasting their time. So we bring a multimodal approach, which is why we take the best of the breed. We take multiple AI models, guardrail it and we put up compliance around it, which means it should not hallucinate. So our AI model has absolutely zero hallucination because we are a small language model, which is a domain specific language model. So we understand what does K3 capital do? What are its it policies? What are its HR policies where we go outside the boundary is what we call as trusted knowledge? For example, I'll give you a classic example. So I'm one of the employees who is probably in a sales department or marketing. And my entire life is happening like collaborating with my colleagues or chat. And I'm sure you would agree most of the conversations happen over teams or slack. Let's say, I'm on teams and I'm not able to access something or something fails. Typically, what do these employees do? They would just go into like, you know, submit a ticket. They would either go to the support portal or they will go to open up their mailbox. What we do is we provide a conversational experience right where they are. So let's say, I'm setting up my outlook and I'm going out of office, maybe I'm new to outlook. I don't know how to do it. So I can simply just post a question to the system saying, how can I do this? How can I get this help? This would be a very simple question saying, how do I set up an out of office? In my outlook? Maybe I'll ask something trivial once this is done. So the system, what it does is, goes deep into your knowledge. It looks up the right solution article helping the users get instant reply in a very summarized structured format. So I said, how do I set up automatic replies when I go out of office? So it came back with an answer saying, if you're using outlook web access, do this process, if you're using outlook for windows or mac, do these processes and every question? Sorry, every answer has what we call as a source attribution giving a lot of credibility and a lot of confidence to the user as well as the system. So this answer is basically coming from an office 365 training guide. So users can literally click and see where this answer is coming from. So they are very confident that, OK, looks like this is a sharepoint site maybe, but I don't have access to it. But yes, this is helpful now. Let's say I would like to recall an email. Maybe I sent out an email in a hurry and I would just like to recall it. How do I do that? The system can quickly guide me in saying, hey, you know what? If you've sent an email, it would be in this section, go ahead and do that. So, it's basically helping me self serve all these day to day support related questions that come through. This is what we call as rag. So here you can see it said go to your sent items folder, open the email. And on the message tag, you should see the recall this message. I can quickly do that. Typically, these will go into the ticket queue even though they go into low priority. There would be an SLA assigned to it. And I'm sure it might take maybe four to five hours of work to be done, but the damage is already done. The message is already gone, right? So this is where our AI works as a copilot. This copilot can literally answer any organization related query or trusted source, what we call any kind of technology products that you have can be enabled with the system. I can even go deeper in terms of, hey, can you show me how to create a pivot table in Microsoft excel? I'm probably new to Microsoft excel. I don't know how to do that. Maybe. Can you show me how I can do vlookup, any question typically, and the system can guide the user, we call it the agent co pilot mechanism. I go a little bit complex, maybe I'll just use some error code. Let's say, OK… let's ask something related to Aws or probably or even hardware related. Let me just ask something on my laptop. So, yeah. So this time it came back to the pivot table, answer saying, select the data sheet and so on. So I'll ask something related to my laptop. Hey, my surface pro is charging very slowly. A typical end user query, which is typically going in as an incident into the system because people might be having some issues on their laptop. Maybe they are running multiple applications. So our system can immediately provide a troubleshooting guide based on what it would have written going through some of these troubleshooting like follow this process, kill all the task manager, see which is taking the cpu and so on. So the system can provide that level one troubleshooting, but then all else fails, you have an option for submitting an incident. This is the device I'm referring to and if needed, the user could maybe just attach a file or probably just take a picture and say, like, okay, this is what I'm seeing. Hey, can you solve this for me? And I can just attach that as an image and submit that as an incident. And you might also notice I'll come back to that. docs.title: call-transcript--Pavan Kandikonda and Sumeet Kumar _ Atomicwork
docs.summary: The discussion revolves around IT service management at the World Bank, focusing on the transition to ServiceNow and interest in AI integration solutions. Participants highlight the challenges and considerations in modernizing their IT infrastructure.
docs.body:

Sumeet Kumar with World Bank
Recorded on Oct 4, 2025 via Zoom, 53m



Participants

Atomicwork
Sumeet Kumar

World Bank
Pavan Kandikonda, Senior IT Officer

Other
P2

docs.title: call-transcript--Prabakaran B and Paige _ Atomicwork
docs.summary: The discussion revolves around implementing a chatbot tool to enhance IT support by enabling end users to resolve queries independently, thereby reducing the workload on the IT team.
docs.body:

Paige Wunderlich with Tekion Corp
Recorded on Aug 20, 2025 via Zoom, 22m



Participants

Atomicwork
Paige Wunderlich

Tekion Corp
Gsarveswaran
Prabakaran B

Other
Prabakaran Balasubramaniam, No Audio Connected,No Video Connected

We are from India bangalore.

docs.title: call-transcript--Skydio _ Atomicwork Planning Session
docs.summary: The session focused on planning future engagements and a product demo for Atomicwork, with discussions about AI integration and information syncing capabilities.
docs.body:
Skydio / Atomicwork Planning Session

Paige Wunderlich with Skydio
Recorded on Sep 30, 2025 via Zoom, 27m



Participants

Atomicwork
Paige Wunderlich
Ken Kaufman, Enterprise Solution Engineer
Raghav Viswanathan, Solution Engineering
Eric Edmonds, Head of Sales

Other
Catalina
Ruby Martinez
Gerardo
Karen Feng



Transcript

0:05 | Paige
hi, again… great. Right. Do we have everyone here from y 'all's side or are we waiting for anyone else? They've been invited? Everyone's in here. Okay. Fantastic. All right. So, I know that we've only got 30 minutes here. So I want to keep us on track for the time that we have today. I know a lot of you. This is our first time meeting. So I want to do a quick round of introductions before we jump right in and then we can get into things. This meeting was initially planned as being a planning call for future meetings and engagements, but I also want to make sure that everyone who is new to… atomicwork has the chance to kind of dig in and take a look around so we can cover that in a moment here too. But I guess I can start us off. So, my name is Paige wunderlich, I am the account executive on the atomicwork side, and I am joined by Ken Kaufman who is a solutions engineer for our team, Raghav who is going to be our head of solutions engineering. And then Eric Edmonds, who is our head of sales. And then I suppose, okay. So, I know Patrick, I know now, Aaron, thank you, Ruby. I've met Karen and Gerardo, would you mind introducing yourselves? 

1:39 | Gerardo
Yeah, no problem. My name is Gerardo. I'm part of the help desk team here at scudio. I'm on the same team with Aaron and Karen. 

1:50 | Paige
Perfect. Hi, I'm Karen, I'm also part of the help desk team. Wonderful. Thank you both appreciate the introductions. So again, we were looking to kind of go through scheduling and planning for taking a look at atomicwork. We were going to go through scheduling a demo that was going to go more in depth with the whole team and some additional departments and also looking at a POC and what was going to be of most importance to you all during that time. I suppose what might be helpful here is understanding how much you all know about atomicwork first. So that if there are any questions right off the bat, we can cover those and then dig in a little bit further. So for those that are new to the idea of atomicwork, Aaron, Gerardo and Karen, do you have any questions to get us started? 

2:55 | Catalina
So, I was actually looking at your guys' product demo on your website and going through your site and everything like that. And a lot of it was using a lot of AI to have people reach out to that. In particular, being that the first line of responding and assisting for the AI training, how do you guys essentially train the bot to improve and everything like that? 

3:26 | Ken
Yeah, I can jump in here. So at its core to provide some information for the AI to learn, there's two main sources of information. You have proprietary information, so that can pull from your own document repository sites. So if you think about tools like notion that you're leveraging today, we can go ahead and connect to that so that we'll sync information over into our tool and it can leverage those documents or information. Second to that is public sources. So if you want to deem, we've over 900 trusted sources on our site. So if we look at apple as an example, they already have fantastic support for things like macbooks and other hardware that they create. So we can just use those and sync information back into our tool as well. So you don't have to worry about keeping up to date some of those support articles that are already publicly available from there. You can also generate, verified answers are just when we want the AI to answer something in the same way every time. So a good example might be the guest WI fi password. So if somebody is wondering what that is, we can always say, hey, if you receive it in these five six, seven different ways, always go ahead and respond in this way. So for the most part, that's how we're starting to train the AI and it can learn over time through some other contexts and situations that it's been in. 

4:51 | Catalina
Okay, cool. So you mentioned that we can use like things from our like notion pages. And also like you said, public information… is there a way to do like both at the same time? 

5:05 | Ken
Yes. Yep. That's built into our platform. So anything relevant, we'll go ahead and check those areas to try to extract the best answer from them. So we're recognizing the intent from that user. Are they looking for information? Are they trying to make a request? And then we leverage those different sources of information to complete a response and provide that back? 

5:27 | Catalina
Okay, cool. Thank you. 

5:28 | Ken
Yeah, of course. 

5:30 | Paige
Thanks for the questions. Any other questions that have come up? And I suppose, Kevin, I don't want to put you on the spot here, but it might be helpful for us to do maybe like… a five minute slack overview of what that would potentially look like just to give a good idea here. And I, obviously, if y 'all don't think that would be helpful or if you've already taken a look… we don't need to dig into that. But if you'd like to see the front end quickly, we can do that just so you've got some context going into the conversation as far as our further meetings and demos. Yeah, Patrick, I see you now. That sounds good. Cool. Okay. Thank you, Ken. Are you okay with that? 

6:24 | Ken
Yeah, yeah, thank you all good. I should have everything pulled up and ready to go here. Give me a shot when you're looking at slack. 

6:34 | Catalina
Yep. See it. 

6:36 | Ken
Okay. So again, we're heavily invested in slack as a channel to try to be that first layer of support for different users and we'll use different knowledge to help deflect things. Another key point is also the context that we're building. So we have this idea called the context management data lake. So we want to be able to store information in there that's going to provide a best in class response. So you can think of that, you know, information that's in other business apps, maybe ptl allotments or how much time accrued they have, or if we need to peek into their assets, understand what assets they have. We're also slowly compiling this information in one area as well to also help inform. So users have two options within slack to get some answers. They can always speak to slack directly or, sorry speak to Adam directly right here from within slack. So you can think of this as like a one to one personal DM with Adam. So if I want to go and ask a question, maybe I need to update my operating system as an example. So I'll jump in and ask Adam that question. You'll see each conversation housed within a thread here. So this will give us a window that we can relate to what type of question or the question that the user is asking while it's looking for that answer, you'll notice some reasoning trails popping up here on the right hand side. So kind of a standard practice. Now, if you've leveraged any other AI tools and how they show a feedback loop to users, hey, this is where I'm looking for that information. Here are the sources I expect. So we'll be able to see that live in a feedback loop. Once this provides me an answer, we can see different options here for how to do just that something like an operating system update. We will cite throughout this example. So you can see some different links to apple articles. So this was actually leveraging some of that public information and letting me know. But one cool thing that I really enjoy about this is I never had to say this was for a MacBook. We already know for example, given that context management data lake that this user has a MacBook pro, we know what type of device they're already using. So I can provide a better answer right off the bat here by linking to that information here and how to update an operating system that's going to be relevant to me. You can always rebrand this as well. So while this is saying Adam and there's our logo, you can always change this. So if you want to rename it something or add your own personal logo in here. You can do so to really personalize this experience. I'll take a quick pause there. Any questions or comments or feedback? 

9:22 | Catalina
If someone is asking questions and the bot isn't able to answer it at all, does it then default to one of the members of our team? 

9:32 | Ken
Yeah. So what it will do in that case, if it's not able to provide a response, it will give you an option to go ahead and generate a ticket within the help desk. So it'll help craft that. So it'll pull information from what your question was to autofill the form for you. So all you have to do is confirm that the information is correct and you can go ahead and fire that off. And we'll also surface those unanswered questions for you. So when you think about improving your knowledge in the future or maybe you need to add a new request item, we'll also provide you with that information as well via analytics to say, hey, this is something I couldn't answer, maybe create a resource so that we can better improve upon this in the future. 

10:13 | Catalina
Okay, cool. 

10:17 | Paige
Awesome. Thank you, Ken. I appreciate you running through that on short notice. So our goal will obviously be to get y 'all a full demo. I just wanted you to have some foundation for what we're going to be talking about today. So that's obviously the front of the system, the back is going to have a lot of your standard itsm modules obviously AI baked in there as that's going to be in a lot of kind of corners of our tool which we can go into further. But I really wanted to understand a little bit more about how we… can help make this evaluation process smooth for you all. So what are going to be the areas in which it's going to be really important for you to know that the tool works and works well for specific use cases, so that we can help to start crafting that POC. So when we get to that point, you feel really confident in the tool being able to handle a lot of your common use cases and maybe even some not so common ones. But we want to make sure that you're feeling really confident in the ability of the tool once we get to that point. So what would that look like for you all? 

11:43 | Catalina
So the way I would kind of see that right now is of course, we try to have our end users go specifically to our portal to put in tickets or if they're messaging us in a slack channel, we have just an open channel called help it where people will just reach out there frequently and then we'll either have them circle back and put in a ticket or we'll put in a ticket or do we use the auto create within the channel itself? Some people do. Yeah. But really the source of having it go to one direction, it's either all in fresh service or all in atomicwork. But I mean slack really want one place that our employees go to do one fine knowledge, not just it HR information data because I know you guys integrate with Google drive notion Jira GitHub if you wanted to, but really being that central repository where anyone can find anything. And then if it's not available, then it creates a ticket for that department specifically based off the subject that's the conversations being had really eliminating all like first level, like trying to triage first and where the ticket should go. 

12:59 | Paige
Okay. Deal. That sounds great. So for kind of sorry, what was that? 

13:07 | Catalina
He was laughing and I was like I said, I've seen it before. 

13:11 | Paige
Yes. And I think that for that more kind of overarching all departmental experience really filtering into that atom app will be helpful. We can also put atom into a channel if you all would like to test it that way. If that's the way that tickets are currently coming in today, our conversations are being started is through that ask it channel. But if our goal really is to have a single source where we are triaging for all of the departments involved. We'll probably want to really focus in on making sure that app experience is ready to go. So that's great to know as far as the backend… is concerned… knowing that all kind of standard modules that you would expect to see do exist back there. Are there any areas that you'd really like to improve upon? Whether it be change management or potentially even like major incidents? Anything along those lines that we'd like to make sure is there and we test out? 

14:22 | Catalina
Change management is always nice to have. So I'd like to see that. And also too do you guys have the capabilities doing like kanban visualization? 

14:32 | Paige
For the ticket point of view? Yeah, not at the moment, but that is something that we've talked about adding into the UI. So as of today, that's not available from the ticket perspective. 

14:47 | Catalina
And I guess then from my perspective, at least to follow up with like dashboards, taking a look at the dashboards again, one more time. 

14:55 | Paige
Okay. That sounds good. And when you say dashboards, are you talking about like? 

15:00 | Catalina
Executive metrics? 

15:02 | Paige
Okay, perfect. Okay. That's easy. We can do that. And then when we're thinking about how it is integrating or how it is working alongside some of these other departments in cases like onboarding and offboarding, where you've got it and HR working together, potentially even something like facilities or workplace… is there a common… grouping of tickets or actions that we'd like to test out as well when it comes to onboarding or offboarding? 

15:44 | Catalina
Sorry, can you repeat that one more time? 

15:45 | Paige
Yeah. So when you're thinking about how it is interacting with some of these other departments, one of the most common use cases that we see where the multiple departments are interacting is something like onboarding or offboarding, do you all have something in place for that today? 

16:02 | Catalina
Right now, in our ticketing system, we do have one for both onboarding and offboarding, I want to say it's separated into multiple steps that require a lot of either automation from HR to enter into their HRIS, which is workday. Actually. Yeah, that was all my thoughts. 

16:26 | Paige
Okay. Yeah. Sorry, Gerardo. Go ahead. 

16:31 | Ken
I was going to jump in if sure, go ahead. Cool. I'll jump in here. Just a couple of follow ups to understand your environment and your use cases a little bit better. So previously, we talked a little bit about asset management, but I'd love to peel back the onion a bit on it. docs.title: call-transcript--Skydio and Atomicwork
docs.summary: This conversation between Atomicwork and Skydio focuses on the challenges Ruby, an IT manager at Skydio, faces with Fresh Service, particularly around automation and reporting limitations. The discussion aims to explore these challenges in detail to identify potential solutions.
docs.body:

Paige Wunderlich with Skydio
Recorded on Sep 24, 2025 via Zoom, 50m



Participants

Atomicwork
Paige Wunderlich
Ken Kaufman, Enterprise Solution Engineer
Eric Edmonds, Head of Sales
Raghav Viswanathan, Solution Engineering

Other
Ruby Martinez

docs.title: call-transcript--Tekion _ Atomicwork _ POC sync (1)
docs.summary: The meeting focused on integrating Atomicwork with other platforms, including Jira and Slack, while discussing upcoming features and testing procedures for user requests and knowledge queries.

docs.title: call-transcript--Tekion _ Atomicwork _ POC Sync (JSM bridge)

docs.title: call-transcript--Third Bridge_Atomicwork __ Introductory Conversation
docs.summary: This document captures a conversation between Atomicwork and Third Bridge's CIO regarding the usage of Freshservice and insights on IT operations, highlighting challenges and the need for better tool administration.
docs.body:
Third Bridge/Atomicwork || Introductory Conversation

Vijay Shankar with Third Bridge Group Limited
Recorded on Jan 31, 2025 via Microsoft Teams, 45m



Participants

Atomicwork
Vijay Shankar

Third Bridge Group Limited
Chris Esposito, Chief Information Officer



Transcript

0:01 | Vijay
Hey, Chris. Good morning. Hi, Chris. Happy New Year. How are you? 

0:10 | Chris
Yes, I'm good. Can you hear me? Okay? I'm not here. 

0:12 | Vijay
Yeah, I can hear you. Fine. No worries. Thank you. How's your, I know it's almost Friday. So, how's your week been so far? 

0:21 | Chris
I'm looking forward to it not being Friday. We're doing year end at the moment. 

0:26 | Vijay
Oh, okay. 

0:29 | Chris
So, yeah, it's a bit manic this week, but yeah. 

0:33 | Vijay
How are you? Good Doing well. Thank you. And thank you. I really appreciate you giving us your time And I was actually like, I was looking at your picture on LinkedIn. Is it an AI generated one? Yeah. Okay. It really looks totally different. I was like, wow, Wow, definitely something AI done. 

0:54 | Chris

1:11 | Vijay
Same same. I put one that was taken like seven, eight years ago. So I just kept it like that because I was, At least I felt that I was looking young. So I did that. By the way, I really appreciate you giving us your time And I know ThirdBridge. I think we used to work with you guys back at Freshworks for consulting and I think some reviews and some feedback stuff. So, I'm sure As a consulting firm, you would be aware of. Is it, I think we've still got Freshservice.

So it's kind of like I would say it's my baby.

But yeah, I think we've got like 15,000 open tickets. We've got 200 workflows we don't use Trying to get data out. In terms of what the support team's time is spent on is quite difficult, But I don't think it's the tool. I think it's the fact that it's not been properly administered or looked after or cleaned up or, you know, it's more down to the kind of nature of the business than it is the fundamentals of using the tool.

So the move to cloud based experience was new And the adoption on the self service portal, people moving away from email was the big thing. So, how do you see that adoption? Like even today? How do you see the biggest channels? Like, are people still using email portal? Where do you think it's evolved into right now? 

4:08 | Chris
I don't think email was ever used. We're not an email company. Really, Everyone lives on Slack. So we've got a Slack bot that you can put slash ticket in and it'll generate the ticket in the portal. You can go in by the web, you know, user interface and create a ticket that way. But I believe most people put just put slash ticket in and fill out the form and it sends it off. And then we have channels where people ask for an update rather than go and look at the ticket status. They'll just chase people. We still have support teams in every office. So a lot of the contact if they're in the office will just be to walk up to the team rather than putting a ticket around. That. We do use fresh service for experts to contact us whether it's you know, where's my payment, I want to change my bank account or, you know, communications externally with them. And then my team, my tech success team also did the triage for like HR queries, you know, finance team queries that type of thing where we're not the one that resolves the ticket, but we are the one that provides the tool and the initial triage process into them. 

5:22 | Vijay
Understood. Makes sense. So basically the entire IT HR, everyone sits within the same platform to provide that experience. But through a chatbot And off lately, I know service also like, I mean, I quit fresh service after the IPO. So after that, it was pretty much like, I know a lot of changes And that's where we started Atomicwork to bring in a new platform, A service engagement experience. Like basically, I'll be very open and honest. Our mission and vision has totally changed in terms of what we're calling as unlocking tomorrow's IT today. So I know you said you're using the Slack chatbot, I mean, the Slack bot, Have you, have you not explored the Freddie AI on it?

The reason is because you said there are 15,000 tickets, right? If you were to just out of your mind, just take a guess, right? Like out of those 15,000 tickets, what would be the majority of those? Just take a wild guess if you can.

For instance. So, there's we've got quite a lot of legacy systems that we're currently getting rid of and modernizing, And then about 16 percent, we're a high attrition business. So, you know, giving out MacBooks, taking MacBooks back in Again. We're a high attrition business. The average age of the company is 23. It's their first job out of university. It's not a particularly easy job. It's often mis sold. They think they're going to do deep research and they're not, They're facilitating research, not doing deep research on the expert network side of the business, On the information services. It's different, but we have far fewer experts internally in that regard. Typically, it takes people about six months now to get up to speed in the job, Right? So if they leave at nine months, we only actually three months of high utilization. Yeah. Exactly.

Exactly. So that exactly is the gap that we are trying to bridge Chris, That ramp up period for an employee. And please keep me honest, right? Within the first six months, what is happening for that user, right? Like maybe I'm overthinking it. But as you said, understanding the company's policies, the knowledge, the job and the work role that they have to do, getting that access, getting the right content with them. So, imagine an agentic system that is an AI copilot that understands your business, that traverses your business logic or your business processes, the knowledge, the data that you have kept in Google, Drive, the Google Docs, or Google workspaces, being able to quickly retrieve, But with the right permission, not everybody can access it because the agents have the reasoning capability to understand who is Vijay, what is Chris's role? Does Chris have access to these documents? Does Chris need permission to receive this? Who is Chris's manager? Who can give access for those documents? Instantly? Providing that resolution, Same way as you said, getting access instead of waiting for a software application access for an hour or two. If I were to get access to an application instantly after approval, I would be more than happy to, and there is one less ticket in your system. Imagine incidents being self healed, in terms of hardware troubleshooting, I'll be happy to show you some of these cool things that we are doing, Self healing of hardware issues. Think of how many times people contact you regarding, hey, this configuration that I did for doing something is failing, You have already build an internal runbook for that. What if an AI agent can take that runbook and self heal and remediate that Today? You might be doing it through PowerShell or Mac shell scripts. If that agent AI agent can actually do, that is where we are actually building Just on a high level. What do you think about such a system, Chris.

I mean, we honestly think we can automate maybe 80 90 percent of the entire research workflow probably by 20 32 and probably 50 percent of it in the next two or three.

Years. Wow. I think with AI, I think that can even go a little bit faster and that can come up faster because now with AI being able to, I mean you can see the new models that the models. I'll just show you something from a deck that I've put together but I'm happy to take any questions. It's just a small presentation before I show you the actual product by the way. And as I said, the whole vision and the mission of the company of course is unlocking tomorrow's, IT today, We want to empower teams and employees with agentic service management where Any information they request any access, they request, any kind of reporting that they want to do, any kind of actionable insights through business processes can be instantly granted or instantly driven by ai agents. So that employees don't get stuck. An employee's job is their day to day activity where they are focused on, they should not be deviated or they should not be frustrated that something is broken. Something is not working. That is exactly where the ai co pilots come coming back to the team. We are a very seasoned team coming from freshworks, coming from Nutanix. it will happen, you know, I think, the vision is 100 percent, right? This will happen. docs.title: call-transcript--Thirdbridge Consulting - Atomicwork Discussion
docs.summary: The discussion focuses on how Third Bridge Group is exploring AI integration and automation within their operations, particularly in tech support and IT service management. Participants aim to assess the merit of utilizing Atomicwork's platform for a pilot demonstration.
docs.body:
Thirdbridge Consulting - Atomicwork Discussion

Vijay Shankar with Third Bridge Group Limited
Recorded on Feb 11, 2025 via Microsoft Teams, 1h 1m



Participants

Atomicwork
Vijay Shankar

Third Bridge Group Limited
Chris Esposito, Chief Information Officer
Flora Gauthier, SVP - Global Operations and Transformation
Steve Sharman, Chief Architect and Global Head of Platform
Fiona Neville, Global Head of Technology Operations



Transcript

0:06 | Fiona
hi, Fiona. Hi, how are you? I am good. Thank you.

I'm doing well. Thank you and a happy new year to you family. Good evening. Actually. I think I'll just quickly check if Chris is, yeah.

Flora is looking at how ai can help the rest of the business. So, you know, particularly around that knowledge getting people at the knowledge curve earlier. So I think Flora, we'll be able to get you more up to speed with some of the roles, that we think ai might be able to assist people on and give you a better understanding of how we do our expert network service. And then Steve is just taking on our head of ai role transitioning from being chief architect, where he's going to take the overall lead on all ai initiatives, for the foreseeable future. And he is looking at whether we can kind of how the integrations would happen from an ai perspective as well. So, you know, the idea being all three of them could take this forward without me, give you a better understanding in context of third bridge, in those use cases, and then give you more time to prepare for a more focused demonstration with a wider audience so that we can assess whether we think this is worth piloting and moving forward. 

4:18 | Vijay
Definitely. Thank you Chris, definitely thank you so much. I'll just do a quick short introduction about myself for the team's sake. And, and thank you Chris, for the introduction to the team, and helping me get us here. So I'm Vijay, I was one of the early first one of the first few co founders at freshworks. And in 20 20 and of course, we built multiple products, fresh desk, fresh service for sales and so on. But predominantly I come from itsm background because in my previous life, I built manage engine products which was on premise help desk products which included some of the zoho network monitoring help desk, and so on. So, the move to cloud was obvious everyone was moving to the cloud. So we built in official a cloud based icsm platform at freshworks. We had a very good ipo… in nasdaq so most of us we came out, we wanted to do something in the ai world. So especially in the generative ai, we thought of building a grounds up it help desk or an idle engine that is ai first. And at the same time process and people first. Today, if you see predominantly the way freshworks or fresh service works is it's ticket first, you log a ticket, and then you get your work done, post the approval word. Ai is all about outcome today. If you even, in research terms, there are so much content people. They prefer to open up a chat gpd portal or they might have an, you might have an internal like Microsoft co pilot, to kind of ask some things, and get things done at a faster rate. So that is exactly what we wanted to build. We wanted to build an ai service management platform agentic. But at the same time something that can go beyond help desk because today… help desk is not just it or hr. It's it's beyond that. People need help with marketing, people need help from sales, people need help from legal accounting, payroll and so on. So how can ai become this one service management layer? How do we bring in a service management layer? But beyond it? So with that, I'll just walk you through a very short deck. I'll not bore you with a lot of ppts, and stuff. And, and I'll quickly jump in to show you the product. As I said earlier, our goal is agentic service management. And our vision and mission as an organization is unlocking tomorrow's, it today. And, as a backdrop, we have raised funding successfully. We raised 40,000,000 us dollars overall. And, and we are of course, a very lean team. We don't we don't believe in… like a big bang team group, both kind of a way we prefer do more with less. And, and one of the most prolific investors in open ai cosla ventures, they have actually invested with us. So we are very proud that an ai backing vc has invested in us. Which means our ai vision is at the right, right methodology. Now coming back to the complexities of today's. Organization employees today have multiple tools, multiple products and multiple systems to engage with email, slack portal, self service portal and so on. And even there are they getting the right information, we don't know it's a mixed bag because they have to do a lot of context switching. How can we navigate that whole experience? That is the whole idea. We wanted to build a very modern software, ai service agent first with a human in the loop. We always want to have a human supervisor who can manage the experience. There. Of course, has to be an agentic process that can execute with the right reasoning. Today. If you look at the workflow engine, even in fresh service, the biggest pain that we saw was you have to create a workflow. And, and last time, if I recall, Chris mentioned, there are like some 100 plus workflows which are sitting idle which are not even being used. You have to create a keyword based workflow, you have to create a routing workflow. And so, why do we have to go that complex? When ai engines today can reason and can understand the context? How do we bring in that experience? Which is why our model works natively out of box in slack, the Microsoft teams or even email or as a of course portal will always be there. You cannot negate it. People want to track and stuff. But our experience remains within the conversational experience, which is a slack or a Microsoft teams where people are able to gather knowledge information from your internal source… or even we introduce something called as a universal agent which can even traverse your browser restricted contents to go open up a browser in the background, and retrieve the information you need. And provided there is a service management layer, idle process will always stay. You need proper approvals, you need proper incident management and of course, root cause analysis and change management to bring in that experience powered by a workflow engine which is also driven by ai agents. Now coming back to what we have seen as a success. Of course, with the platform, we're close to 65 to 75 percent of self service with the whole with the platform which we'll talk about, in the in. The background now, we are focused heavily on security. We don't because ai engines, people are a little bit worried. Am I putting my personal data? I'm sorry about that. Someone's knocking on the road. Apologies. I'm so sorry. 

10:19 | Vijay
