So, how can this copilot start engaging with the employee from their day one to make their experience much better, something related to basic stuff within the organization, things that might involve a lot of questions to their seniors instead, how can atom take that ownership? So that is the whole idea on top of that, you have your it processes, your service, catalog designers, even workflow builders work because we felt even if ai takes that ownership, people still want to build workflows. So there is a visual workflow engine to create those workflow actions, but you will have ai actions here, prompt based workflow building and all. And of course, this is where what we call a skills where, you can connect to multiple idps to execute remote actions, whatever today is being done over an orchestration model through the workflow engine can be. Done through an agentic model like reset my password, install this software for me. Can you give me access to the software and so on with this? I'll pause. And by the way, it's a robust ecosystem, what I mean by that is being able to connect to your Google workspace, your notion, your team slack any of those systems. You can even connect to your Jira's of the world, your Salesforce of the world, any external data source, any knowledge source or anything where people can use atom as a personal assistant, connect your knowledge source like Salesforce to say, salespeople can ask like, hey, show me all the accounts that I'm working with. Show me the status of the top 50 accounts that I'm working on, what is the revenue last quarter? Provided you have the right permission to do that. I'll pause here. Team. Any questions? I know we have five more minutes, any thoughts? 

54:27 | Flora
I had a small one on the onboarding workflow. So, so how autonomous is it? For example, I think one of the actions was like schedule a check in or something. Yeah, does it then go in the calendar and schedule the check in? Or does it remind the person to do that? 

54:44 | Vijay
You can do both. Basically, if connected to my Google calendar or my team's calendar, it can add a calendar based on the user's availability, or it can just directly override that. Or we can even add a task to set up a one on one. Some, some customers that we spoke to, they said we don't want to do a direct calendar ad. So you create a task and you notify them over a slack that, hey set up a one on one with your manager next 30 days or something like that in their calendar, giving the calendar link. And so on some said, we will go ahead and give acts because, it's more easier rather than asking them to do one more step. So it's a configuration. It's a configuration approach. You can choose what you prefer to do in those terms. But the latter where you add a task and ask them to schedule a schedule. A one on one is a more preferred way because managers might be busy, they don't want to be added without their, you know, like an engagement with them. Like I would want to be checked first. Like, hey, are you free this day? So I can set up a one on one kind of a way. So we see that most customers prefer that way. 

56:04 | Flora
And it's configured by each employee or a company wide or team. 

56:11 | Vijay
It's a, it's a configuration you can choose. So, the good thing about journeys as a construct is journeys can be assigned manually, you as an admin or as an hr person can say, hey, let me assign this journey to x or something, or you can do it based on the employee type or the employee attributes. So you can say like, hey, everybody who is in the sales team has to set up like let's say every six months, there has to be a manager check in. So I can say after six months, everybody go ahead or after like let's say 12 weeks or 15 or 20 weeks or something, go ahead and set up a one on one with their manager. But what should be the department? Like should it be for the sales department or should it be for all the members? So I can say anyone who is part of say engineering, you have to this journey will automatically be assigned to your profile. And since we engage or interact with your hrms, I didn't ask last time, you know, what is your hrms? 

57:22 | Chris
Sage people? 

57:24 | Vijay
Sage got it. So we can interact with sage to capture that information to say, Vijay is from sales, Vijay is from engineering and have this data flow through sage itself. The good thing here also is we are taking a platform based approach where we natively embed this… it's a marketplace of using hrms or hras tools. So this provides us with all the apis that is needed early on. So we connect with this system called merge dev. And of course, there is another one called nango where we basically look at all the different apps and we use, would it be this sage or this one? There are two sage that I see sage people. Yeah, this is the one sage people. Yeah. So, we natively pull the data from your sage people to say, what is Vijay's profile? When was Vijay? When did Vijay join? What is Vijay's department? What is his payroll runs? We want to allow for applying off time of getting his or her salary information, paychecks. And so on. So the data flows through the sage people model. And we would have those journeys assigned to the people because there's a scheduler, the scheduler is running every day every 30 minutes to kind of capture, that job. The moment it identifies that this person matches this criteria, the journey gets assigned to them. So, that kicks in and they are able to action out based on the people matching the criteria. I hope that answers your question. 

59:11 | Vijay
And by the way, the good thing about the platform that we are seeing is the extensibility for the ai agents to multiple teams or multiple departments, especially in terms of knowledge or learning because people don't want to always go on and it's two way, right? Organizations don't want people to be searching outside the ecosystem. They don't want them to go on a chat gpt and do some search which could be proprietary even if you look at it. I mean, like last we spoke, Chris mentioned about Google gemini being used for internal. We want to be that copilot which has the internal knowledge as well as… external with the compliance. So that people don't go outside their ecosystem, which is the slack. So within slack itself, I can ask, hey, can you quickly do a research about this company that could be enabled as a flag? What I mean by that our assistant can be enabled with certain content. So you can say, hey get me some arts and entertainment, get me some data about events and financial markets, get me data about, say, something academic or something like that. So you control the behavior of the ai model on the compliance. I don't want people to talk about politics. I don't want people to talk about hateful content and so on. So you can control the ai behavior as an administrator. So people use the platform within the constraint of it. 

1:01:01 | Chris
Thanks, Vijay. Are we up on time? So this was a kind of itsm, biased demo of the platform. Fiona, you're going to be off for just under a month but obviously gives you some time to reflect around that. And then I'll catch up with Steve and Flora later this week. And if you think it's worth all trying to target a demonstration on the use cases that I said at the start, Vijay, then I'll leave Flora and Steve to come back to you directly. Excellent. Thank you very much for your time. 

1:01:36 | Flora
Really interesting. Thank you. Thanks all. Thank you. Bye. Have a good evening. Bye.

docs.title: call-transcript--URMC _ Atomicwork - quick sync
docs.summary: This document details a quick sync between Atomicwork and Upson Regional Medical Center discussing potential partnership and product interest, highlighting positive feedback from various stakeholders.
docs.body:
URMC | Atomicwork - quick sync

Justin Cooper with Upson Regional Medical Center
Recorded on Sep 25, 2025 via Zoom, 29m



Participants

Atomicwork
Justin Cooper
Eric Edmonds, Head of Sales

Upson Regional Medical Center
Erik Bowe, Director of IT



Transcript

0:00 | Erik
hello? 

2:09 | Erik
Hey, Justin. Hey. 

2:10 | Justin
Eric, I'm doing well. How are you? 

2:13 | Erik
Crazy busy, but good. 

2:14 | Justin
Yeah. Well, hey, I appreciate you hopping on such short notice here. 

2:19 | Erik
Perfect. 

2:22 | Justin
We've also got Eric Edmonds from the atomicwork team. Eric, you on with us? 

2:28 | Eric
Yep. How's it going? Eric? Nice to meet you. 

2:31 | Erik
Same here. 

2:31 | Justin
Eric with a K and Eric with a C. I don't know how I'm going to have to differentiate y 'all but awesome, Eric, one, I wanted to introduce Eric with a C to you, Eric is our head of sales here. So, Eric, if you wanted to say a quick hi. 

2:47 | Eric
Yeah, yeah, no, great to meet you. Eric, appreciate it. Just wanted to hop on and say, hi. I know Justin has been working with the team. I actually had a baby about a month ago, so I've been kind of in and out. So I missed some of these calls, but I've kind of been watching in from the outside, so it's great to meet you. We really appreciate the time that you guys have given and the opportunity to show the product and go through this potential partnership. So really appreciative, just wanted to hop on, see if there was anything I could add about as far as being a resource for you and just make sure you had my contact information. If there's anything you need post this. I'll make sure to send over my contact information so that you have it, but just wanted to hop on and say hi. So we appreciate it. 

3:32 | Erik
Okay. I appreciate it. I appreciate y 'all's time and demoing the product to us and so forth. 

3:38 | Justin
Awesome. So, yeah, I mean, just post the conversation with Melinda and Marshall yesterday. Just a couple of things I wanted to confirm and verify. So obviously they let me know about some of the budget timelines that y 'all have with needing to get numbers over kind of ASAP. So just wanted to clarify a couple of things. And first of all, from an exciting perspective, it sounds like everybody had really positive things and feelings towards atomicwork and at this point, we're kind of nudged in as that vendor of choice for y 'all. 

4:07 | Erik
absolutely. Justin. So, I had great conversations with our HR director. She struggles with her front office being a revolving door and trying to get people out of there and picking up phones and trying to route things in through a ticketing system. So, she was 100 percent on board. I think she watched the general demo that you had recorded on the it side. I, our facilities director, it's a slam dunk. He's with maintenance connection through a current right now. It's like three versions behind or something. He doesn't even like the new version. So, he's ready. He's ready to dump it and go to one. And then the surprise one I thought was, our soon to be CFO, he's our associate CFO, he'll become our CFO, on 10 one when our existing CFO retires. And so, he immediately chimed in when, I was talking about it, and he said, I want, I need that for the payroll office. So, it was pretty much a slam dunk across the board for those three including us in it. So that's what he told me. I said, I can't make the touch point tomorrow, you know, relate to you all. Hey, we have definitely an interest from a pricing perspective to bundle at least the four of our units together. And, you know, for us, on the it side having a change control module, if that's you know, being priced out, separate, integrated in, with the help desk component of it. You know, it's a must for us. So, at the end of the day, it team loved it because what I told them, I'm not going to disrupt any workflows in here if it wasn't efficient. But, Melinda and her team talked it through and, I talked it over with the clinical it team and everybody's 100 percent on board for changing out, moving away from landsweeper. So, you know, we're going to keep them as our asset management system and then lean into all for help desk and chain management. 

6:03 | Justin
Okay. That's awesome. No. And it's great to hear. And I talked to Melinda too because obviously, I know there's some time between budget submission and budget approval. So kind of coming back to the table if needed to connect with some of those teams, you know, individually, 

6:16 | Erik
To. 

6:16 | Justin
address any questions, but obviously, we can cross that bridge when we get there, but at least threw it out there, as an option, if they do want to have more in depth conversations just to. 

6:26 | Erik
build a confidence around the tool. We're happy to do that. Yeah, absolutely. So, in terms of budgeting timelines, we are going into budget planning here. I've got to have a plan, my preliminary plan, ready to go, cause I report directly to the CEO, and we're going to talk through some of those in our admin team meeting on the thirtieth. So, I need some sort of a rough estimate as to what, you know, from you as to what this is going to pull off because we will do this as a Cy 26 capital project. So, believe Melinda mentioned, you know, my, desire to have any sort of multi year, lock in and pricing that we possibly can, because obviously, if I'm going to capitalize this, it can't just be a one year subscription. I have to have more than one year, meaning two, four, five, many vendors will do that with, who have moved to subscription models have been very flexible and they're more than happy to lock in prepaid upfront for three years, five years. So I don't know if that works on your side, but just know that's what I'm, going to be leaning into for a minimum of two, preferably three to five yep. 

7:37 | Justin
Yeah, I spoke with Eric a little bit about it yesterday, and I think we're starting to put all that together, from a multi year perspective. So we should be good on that front. I guess, I'm just more before diving into some of the specifics on the pricing side, from a budgeting perspective? I guess what does the process look like? We'll get you all the numbers you all, have your meeting, on 10, nine 30. I guess what happens between then and November? Does that go to some sort of board who has the final approval? Or what does that just overall process look? 

8:08 | Erik
Like, we're just on the thirtieth going to be actually reviewing, all of the budget assumptions that we have for each of our areas on the administration team. Basically, what will happen then is on October the first, there will be a release of, the capital and operating budget sheets. So, then be released to all leaders, all enter in everything in there. And then they're going to be all due back by October fifteenth and, any functions then being presented to our board finance committee. Assuming all of those go, well, then basically a draft budget summary will be back to us sometime around the November eleventh, timeframe and then final board of trustees approval will, happen on December seventeenth and as soon as cutting it close, but assuming, they rubber stamp everything in there. Usually, it's you know, it's more of a formality than anything that, you know, the question, you know, obviously really big expenditures, mri machines and cat scan machines. Yeah, that, so at the end of the day, then it would be a January 126 implementation for obviously, our fiscal year budget which aligns with our calendar year. So, that being said, that is my current game plan. I'm, also going to alternate, alternatively submit this, you know, the rural health technology grant as part of the one big beautiful bill is out and rolling and, applications are supposed to be into our hands at the end of the month as well with everything back by November the first, I am going to put you all as a line item in there as well because obviously, if we can get federal government to pay for it, as part of that, grant and initiative and bill, we're going to lean into that and use our capital and operating dollars for other things. And so that would probably follow a very similar timeline. The thing I'm seeing from that timeline perspective and bear with me for a minute. I gotta pull that one out here real quick. Basically, most of those decisions and award decisions are supposed to be made by December 30 first. With basically a January 126 rollout for all of the funds. So, either way, I'm, going to, I'm, going to go down both paths because we want this product in one way or another. And we need a new help desk system and I need a change control platform because I keep getting written up for it. And so at the end of the day, it was my first time being written up for it. We, when I was the dba here, you know, Melinda would come in and say we got to do something, we got to do. Something, and I'm like, yeah, I know somebody needs to back up a money truck, at the end of the day, one way or another, I've got two paths into getting this funded. And so, I don't potentially see any barriers with it simply because now, I've got others who will probably, what will probably happen is all the capital will lean into it, but if need be, the HR director, our CFO, our facilities director, we'll put, we'll take whatever total amount you've got and divide it four ways and make sure it hits all of our capital budgets to spread, so it can get through that way too. 

11:35 | Justin
Okay. That was actually going to be my next question was, because it's multi department, is the budget going to be spread out kind of equally amongst it? Obviously because it's a more, obviously, those departments will be using the backend, but it does really touch all employees in terms of being able to access, the help desk specifically. So, yeah. 

11:54 | Erik
I, absolutely, if I said it had to come out of operating, everybody was all, you know, very much on board with, hey, I need to pay my portion of it, since we want to try and shoot, assuming we can get, you know, multi year, sort of agreement with you all in subscription, then, you know, that's, the CFO's recommendation to me is we take the high road and go capital, because it's always easier for us to get capital. 

12:21 | Justin
Yeah. Okay. Cool. No, that's great to hear. And thanks for the clarification. Appreciate that. The other point that I wanted to clarify, and I don't know if Melinda filled you in at all. But just in terms of how we do our licensing, we're a bit different from like, the land sweeper or even like a service now, in terms of, our pricing model specifically, as we price by employee, as opposed to, like an agent that actually is in the backend working tickets, 

12:52 | Erik
This morning, yes. 

12:53 | Justin
Okay. So, just to confirm your overall employee count, what is the total fte count, at epson? 

13:02 | Erik
I was supposed to have that ready for you and I've gotten so pulled in different directions here this morning. Let me jump in. She and I had that conversation. I think she's, quoted you 900. And as she and I talked through that, I said, you know, you know, how does, then, do we need to take into account HR's usage of this facilities? So we kind of ruled out, the need for our telespecialists and others. So, if you bear with me, what we finally agreed on is, I said, why don't, we just take a look at our security group for all staff members and pull that number. And she was like, yeah, yeah, that's probably would work. So at the end of the day, give me a second here. I am trying to jump into my active directory pool set to see how many users we have in that group. I know it's well over a 1,000. So, we bantered around, you know, 1,200, 1,500, until we said no, let's just look at how many we have in that security group. And then we'll pad it by some amount to ensure that we've got, you know, potential growth as our CEO has some ambitious plans for growth over the next few years. That being said, as I try and figure out how to type my password here, if we do come in, say, to a multi year agreement and we go with let's say it's a 1,000 users and we end up growing this hospital and it all of a sudden we become 1,400 employees. My assumption is there'll be, you know, a way to do an addendum to the master license agreement that we have contractually to add on additional users? 

14:46 | Justin
Yeah, 100 percent. And within our agreement, we do account for what we'll call employee flex. So to be able to go above kind of that count, and then within a multi year, we'll also, kind of contractually put in, you know, what we would expect that growth to look like just to prepare for it. But we can do some type of true up. Usually, it's like a semi annual true up, over that employee count. So, a lot of flexibility in terms, of kind of how we get to that. 

15:14 | Erik
Yeah, cause I'm in the midst of negotiating, my Microsoft M3, six to five licensing coming into the new year too, and, Melinda and I had to kind of nickel and dime things through for the temporary growth. We're kind of going through. So, at the end of the day, found out they had a max seat count that we could put in there that we can grow up to, and still hit the same po, but only be billed for the initial, amount. So, it's like, okay, that works for me. So I was hoping something similar might exist with you. All all right here, administrative user group directory… find that group here real quick… staff. 

16:27 | Erik
Me. 

16:42 | Erik
I'm sorry, I'm not prepared for this. 

16:45 | Justin
I'm not finding. 

16:46 | Erik
What I'm looking for. I most certainly can email you a number. 

16:51 | Justin
Okay. 

16:51 | Erik
Once, once I locate it. 

16:54 | Justin
Okay. Cause, we'll definitely want that, just, to be able to calculate, those kinds of price potentials and remind me when, you need budget by, when do you need to submit your numbers? 

17:09 | Erik
I'm going to have to present those numbers on Tuesday, the thirtieth, obviously, I would love to have it much sooner than that. So, I can, you know, start, you know, you know, my plans for putting that presentation together. 

17:27 | Justin
Okay. Yeah, I think, we can commit to getting some to you definitely before the end of the week. I'll push for earlier. I mean, me and Eric are both in California for a couple of conferences, but we can absolutely put something together here, and get it over to you well before the thirtieth, so, you've got some time to kind of look over it, but I guess just in terms of, and I'm, glad we had this conversation because I did just want to at least talk it through, to get a pulse check prior to just sending you the quote, just to make sure that we're kind of cooking with gas and all on the same page here. But, you know, assuming that we're going off, that 900 employee number, you know, generally speaking, we're going to be roughly around, that 10 dollar per employee, range on a cost perspective. So, is that aligning kind of with your budget expectations especially since we're looking at spreading this out across the four departments? 

18:26 | Erik
Yeah… I would say so.

Okay, cool. No, that's good to know. What I wanted to avoid was just, you know, obviously, we haven't had any conversations regarding pricing and to us to just send it over blindly. I would much rather have had this conversation beforehand so I'm glad that's kind of in line with what your expectations were. But I think we'll still be able to put something together that'll be attractive for at least the 900 to start. We'll use that as a baseline. And then if you want to send me over that final number, we can adjust accordingly but Eric, I saw you come off mute. 

18:59 | Eric
Yeah, I was just going to, I was just going to say, well, we'll do, Eric, we'll send it over. Typically, what we see through kind of these budget cycles and going through procurement is, you know, we'll send over what we, you know, we'll put in the three year discount, we'll put in the volume discounts, all of those types of things. So that you see it, just know if there's anything you feel like. Hey, this is going to struggle through the budgeting process, let us know and we're happy to work with you. There's a couple of things we have working for us. You guys are a nonprofit which is great. Our, our CEO, you know, wants to work, with companies like this. You guys are obviously doing something great. You know, overall, so if there's any feedback that you have on that pricing and you feel like, oh, we need to tweak this or we need to do something differently. Our biggest goal is to partner with you guys. So we're happy to work, work with you and make sure, that it gets there. The fact that it's a, you know, three to five year agreement is definitely going to help. I think that gives us some flexibility also. So, I, my big ask, you know, coming into this obviously from the outside is just keep it a, keep it an open communication and let us know, if there is anything that you think increases the chance, that it goes through that budgeting process… that, this works, that's priority one for us? 

20:19 | Erik
Okay. That is absolutely great to hear. And I'm glad you mentioned that because, you know, it's the point with some vendors out there. You know, when I mentioned we're a nonprofit, you know, hospital where our, you know, our safe category with feds is because we serve, you know, underrepresented groups, you know, we write off almost 1,000,000 healthcare to the community. So, and a lot of them just laugh us away, and don't give us anything matter of fact, Microsoft, you recently changed everything and it took away an additional discount that we had as a rural health hospital, but yet we apply for all these, you know, federal grants and we receive them because, you know, grant we're not, you know, a level two trauma hospital, but, you know, we, you know, we're we got 115 beds, you know, pretty, pretty substantive size, for Thomas and Georgia. Let me give you that final number I got in, and so, that group currently has about 1,315 people in it, but Melinda and I were talking there's some, about 50 to 75 people. We have to clean up in that. So, if we want to set that total number to 1,400 employees, that should give us about a fudge factor of 100 or so. Okay? 

21:39 | Justin
And then just forward thinking, I know your CEO has ambitions to grow the hospital. Look, just considering a multi year deal, is accounting for like a 10 percent 12 percent growth, on an employee headcount, year over year, kind of a safe growth metric, or what do you think on that? 

22:02 | Erik
I would say probably on that because I've kind of already built that into my head for at least the next two years by saying 1,400, at the end of the day. So, yeah, I'm going to say right now, we're probably sitting in about 12, 12, 25 in there for the all staff members. And, and I had confirmed with Melinda earlier this morning that none of our telespecialists are in there or contractors or others. So basically, well, technically, some of our contract, our locums are. So, at the end of the day, they use our email system, they would use our ticketing system and so forth. So, we have, we wanted to make sure we were given a, you know, a true count, of people who are utilizing the system even though they may not be directly employed by us. So at the end of the day, I'd say that 1,400, would take us at least through the end of 20 27. Then after that, I don't really have a good sense for that yet, Justin, so, no, he's still working through a lot of strategic planning with the board and so forth. If I had to guess, it would probably be something very, minuscule like one percent, two percent. 

23:11 | Justin
Okay. That's good to know. I think we could, we can have it more flatlined than anything. Yeah. So, that makes sense. Okay. And then, I guess just last thing in terms of kind of ironing out timing. And I think if we can affirm this with, just talking through, it, with Melinda too, we'll get budget confirmation, end of November. You all would ideally look to begin implementation in January. Is that kind of the goal? 

23:42 | Erik
Yes, it most certainly would be, just re, up last month. I believe it was my, land sweeper. So at the end of the day, basically, you know, what? We'll re up, just the asset management side of things with them. And, you know, July, August timeframe of next year. So, I figure we should be up and running with atomicworks and, you know, long before then if we were to start that implementation in January. 

24:16 | Justin
Okay. That, that's perfect. Obviously, anytime we start implementing around the holidays, I think it gets a little bit crazy. I guess just from a contract execution perspective, are we envisioning obviously getting budget approved? I talked to Melinda a little bit, just about, you know, in parallel, happy to start, you know, any kind of security review, just to get ahead of that, but is it realistic to think that we would be executing agreements in December? 

24:48 | Erik
I think it's feasible after that December seventeenth timeframe assuming the board approves everything, I would say, most certainly we can start getting everything lined up to execute. So, when we get into January second, we can, you know, that really probably that week of January the fifth, a lot of us, I think took those two days off, sure again. So, at the end of the day, not that you really get off at a hospital, but, definitely coming into that week of January, the fifth, assuming everything are officially released that, you know, we can, I can start pushing that through the procurement process. 

25:27 | Justin
Okay. And what does that typically look like going through the procurement process? 

25:31 | Erik
Is actually here stunningly, quick. Assuming I've got everything lined up, everything's signed. We could start doing preliminary work right now. Like me, your, our baa to you all you sending them, so I can start working that through the approval process that typically takes the longest. When it comes to, hey, I fill out the procurement requests. I've got all the right approvals, you know, it's happened in as fast as an hour. Typically, I give it about three days because the CEO now, is sending all contracts through him for signature. And, you know, obviously, I want to have everything in my head. I'm already planning to have as much lined up as possible because I think he will become that bottleneck in January if everybody all at the same time. So, you're already reading my mind, Justin, that I'm planning on having things lined up where I need to, okay, like this ready to go, baa's already done things of that nature. 

26:37 | Justin
Yeah, I'd say, the sooner we can start the document review process, we're on board. We did talk to Melinda yesterday. If you all have a baa, we're happy to review that. So any other documentation that you need from us from a security perspective, just let me know. I'll shoot you over our trust site as well. That'll have a lot of that documentation. So just so you have it, and then if there's anything else that you need that you don't see on that trust site, just let me know and we can make sure that we, get that over to you ASAP. 

27:05 | Erik
Okay. 

27:06 | Justin
Okay. I think that's all the ammunition that I need, atomicwork Eric, anything else from you? 

27:16 | Eric
No, no, this was great. We're like I said, we're excited. We really appreciate the time, look forward to kind of going into this next phase. We'll just continue talking. We'll we'll get that over to you as soon as possible so that you have it and you can start to prep. But if there's anything else you need even, over, you know, even today double days, just let us know and we'll continue to work with you but excited, to potential partnership. 

27:40 | Erik
Yeah, that's absolutely. So. You know, when I kind of came across you all, in 20 24, you know, it's like this kind of looks like exactly what would fit, you know, here up some regional medical center. And I'm just glad, you know, the rest of the it team, clinical it team, you kind of saw what I saw back in August, September of 20 24. When I came across your website looking for just a change control system because everybody agreed it's definitely a very simplified product integrates with the change control we're looking for and allows us to get away from what is a defunct help desk platform with landscape works. Yep. Awesome. 

28:36 | Eric
Awesome. 

28:39 | Justin
Well, ups, and Eric, thank you so much for hopping on so short notice. I think we've got everything that we need. Let me get to work, on getting this over to you and you've got my commitment, take this over to you definitely before the end of the week. I'll try to get it over to you just ASAP that way we can have, you know, if you do have any questions, we can hop on a quick call, just talk through anything but, super helpful. I'm glad we were able to have this conversation. I'm excited like, to echo, Eric, very excited about, the partnership here, and looking forward, to hammering some things out. 

29:09 | Erik
Absolutely. And I'll get that BA, you know, to you as soon as we're off. Okay? 

29:15 | Justin
Sounds good. We'll talk soon. Okay? All right. Bye everybody.

docs.title: call-transcript--Valerie Oliver and Paige _ Atomicwork
docs.summary: Valerie Oliver from Green Thumb Industries discusses the challenges of using multiple software systems for operational efficiency and seeks a solution to consolidate communication and issue tracking with Atomicwork.
docs.body:
Valerie Oliver and Paige | Atomicwork

Paige Wunderlich with Green Thumb Industries
Recorded on Sep 30, 2025 via Zoom, 33m



Participants

Atomicwork
Paige Wunderlich

Green Thumb Industries
Valerie Oliver, Director Sales Operations



Transcript

0:00 | Valerie
hello, Paige. Can you hear me? Oh, I can't hear you. It looks like your mute button's on though. 

0:07 | Paige
That would be the case. Yes, thank you. Hi. How are you? 

0:11 | Valerie
I'm alrighty. How are you? 

0:13 | Paige
I'm doing well. Thanks, really nice to meet you, nice. 

0:16 | Valerie
To meet you. Sorry for my slight delay there. It's been a wild morning on my side. So I apologize. 

0:26 | Paige
Well, you know, Mondays have a habit of doing that to us, don't. They. 

0:30 | Valerie
Indeed. Ugh. 

0:32 | Paige
Well, hopefully we can make this a less painful part of your morning. So, I did a little bit of digging and I'm really interested to hear about how you came across atomicwork and what you're looking to potentially accomplish with a tool like atomicwork? 

0:55 | Valerie
Yep. So… I have been flexing my Google skills, okay, looking for… services out there that can help me address some challenges that we keep seeing over and over again here at dti. Essentially, the… I think the core of the issue is the fact that we have good news. We're a 1,000,000,000 dollar company. Now, bad news. We're still trying to do everything through excel and we're still mixing and matching multiple softwares, which can lead to confusion and longer lead times to, I mean, our ultimate goal for everybody is to take care of our customers, right? Because that's how we all make money. 

1:53 | Paige
Yep. 

1:53 | Valerie
Even if those customers are internal versus an external, the goal is you got to take care of people so that we… can finish the transaction and make the money, right? So… keep in mind, we are a cannabis company. Yep. So, a lot of what has happened due to regulations, the efficiencies we may have learned in Massachusetts might not work in Maryland, which might not work in New Jersey due to regulations, right? From a regulatory system standpoint, there are three main systems gti works with. One is biotrack, right? Another is metric, and the third is Mj. Freeway. 

2:49 | Paige
Okay. 

2:49 | Valerie
So, you have three different systems due to regulatory determination… not gti determination that's going to add some hitches in your communication, right? Because already you've got three different required softwares versus one. We, as a company use Microsoft suite products. So, Microsoft teams, outlook, power, automate, et cetera, which is good. 

3:25 | Paige
But. 

3:25 | Valerie
There's… not really a CRM, okay. At this time and so, trying to document concerns… whether that be due to a delivery error or pricing… error or anything. There's not really a single source of truth. Okay? So, communication can come through email teams… text message, An offshoot comment during a meeting. I joke around about carrier pigeon or a high five in the middle of the hallway because those are also possible, right? Solid. Yeah. So, what I'm looking for is a software solution where I can start to remove all of the noise. 

4:22 | Paige
Right. 

4:23 | Valerie
And start to consolidate when there are issues into one system, Which will allow us to see how quickly are we able to resolve issues? Did we resolve all the issues? And if we haven't resolved an issue, who's on deck and what's holding us up? Okay? 

4:47 | Paige
Okay. 

4:48 | Valerie
And it sounded like atomicwork could work with the Microsoft suite, 

4:53 | Paige
But. 

4:54 | Valerie
It sounded like I might be able to, I didn't know what I'm gonna call it magic, we would do, but it looked like there might be a way to… put outlook in there as well as teams in there so that we could start to maybe, for lack of a better term, create a social tag, and then use that social tag to track the work and make sure it's all getting done within your platform. But that's why I'm reaching out because yep, sometimes me googling doesn't really give me what actually is out there, right? Yeah. 

5:31 | Paige
Yeah. Okay. So, this is interesting. Okay. So, the teams that would be, so the folks that would be requesting help, or submitting issues, those would be internal employees, correct? 

5:45 | Valerie
Great question. So, I… would say, for wave one, it would be internal communication that we would want to address. And then eventually wave two, we'd want to address communication from our dispensaries… right? And those could be both, gti dispensaries as well as, I'm gonna call them wholesale dealers rather than. 

6:17 | Paige
That makes sense. So, for the gti dispensaries, and, sorry to get into the nitty gritty it'll just help me to understand better. Yeah. So, for those dispensaries, are they also on your like internal teams instance, or would they be typically submitting issues via email at that point? 

6:36 | Valerie
Great question. The short answer is, they too could be text message, high five in the hallway, teams message, outlook, random comment in a meeting, you know, they're definitely part of the I'm gonna call it the mess. 

6:56 | Paige
Okay. All right. So, that helps. So, and then as far as the teams that are working internally to fix these issues, what are all of those teams that, you know, those separate either departments, or teams? What would those look like? As far as, you know, is this like legal or is this, like finance? What, what would all those teams be? 

7:24 | Valerie
Great question. So, I'm gonna oversimplify it. Okay. And I'm gonna put it into three buckets for now. Perfect. Bucket one, let's call it the, the CPG, the packaged… good location. Let's try bucket two as sales. 

7:46 | Paige
Okay. 

7:46 | Valerie
And then bucket three, we'll go ahead and call accounting and finance. 

7:52 | Paige
Perfect. Okay, really helpful. So, I will tell you maybe a little bit about atomicwork and see in some areas where, I think I can see some overlap or some areas where I think we would do really well together but also share some areas that I think might not jive perfectly. And then we can decide if we want to, continue on. So, so atomicwork was created initially as an HR and it ticketing tool. So, when problems arise, you, you initially would have that conversation with Adam, who is our AI agent on teams. If Adam is unable to assist you and Adam gains knowledge from your internal knowledge base and documentation as well as external knowledge bases and documentation, and how, challenges have been resolved with, like historical data on tickets. Oh, okay. And will help to answer questions on the front end. If Adam is unable to resolve those questions, the end user being typically an employee or, you know, potentially a vendor or a dispensary, would be able to then submit a ticket to the back end system that then these three teams would be able to, accept that ticket, go through what Adam did to troubleshoot, and then respond from there to hopefully resolve the ticket right from, in the system. So, the areas that I think would be really helpful based on what you're saying would be that initial intake, where if we can culturally get folks to, potentially have, the conversation or, you know, that high five in the hallway, but then also use, teams and use Adam, they could potentially get, some front end help, and some quick help because Adam is obviously available. But also that back end ticketing would allow for all of these teams to maintain a really solid database of the types of questions that are being asked, where issues are arising, where potential bottlenecks are occurring. And really to help to keep, that flow of work, a little bit more manageable than it sounds like it is today. So, I think those are the areas that, we would do really well together on. You will also see in the tool that we do have a lot of it specific modules. So, things like changes and problems. That would likely just not be something that you would all, you would need to use. But you could know that it would be there. If, you know, the it team ever decided, to utilize a tool like atomicwork, they would have access to those things. So, does that sound like something? Does that sound like what you were initially looking for when you were going through, your Google research? 

10:58 | Valerie
It's definitely a component of what I was looking for. I was looking for a bit of a self… help opportunity, right? So, if there, when there are standard, work instructions or sops, we would be able to share those through something to help people help themselves. 

11:26 | Paige
Yes. 

11:29 | Valerie
In many cases that's really what we need is just, please follow the process please. 

11:38 | Paige
Yeah. And I think, the other area in which Adam is really helpful, we have, this concept of Adam as being, a universal agent. So, it's accessible through a browser. So it can actually, you can share your screen. You can talk through things. Adam can learn your sops, by, being given access to those documents and then can help talk people through, the actual steps that they need to take. So really helpful, you know, obviously for folks that are newer in their roles, or even folks that might've been around for a while and just don't really love to look at the sops. So that's absolutely something that can be done. 

12:31 | Valerie
What about… one example of a ticket we have today, gti… delivers product to Bob's dispensary, and at… the time of delivery, it's discovered we have missed… a crate. So, one of the ticket types that I'm looking to do is be able to track when we have overshipped or undershipped a product or maybe… the wrong product was shipped. Maybe instead of a, vape, pen, we shipped chocolates, it's extreme shouldn't happen, but it does, how would Adam be able to support us? Or would that be more where I might need to take the it tool and perhaps bend it to my needs? 

13:38 | Paige
Yeah. So, that would be dependent on where, what tool? And is it one of the three that you mentioned that is you're doing almost like inventory management or you're doing the shipping through, 

13:53 | Valerie
Good question. Yes. So today we use the, we call them the seed to sale systems. So, metric biotrack, Mj freeway, those are the regulatory, systems we will use to manage our inventory. And those would be, our source of truth. So, when a store notifies us that they've received incorrect, the product that they've received did not match the manifest. It's both a regulatory risk as well as a financial risk for us. And so, I'm looking for a way to track those I'm going to call it tickets, so that we can improve accuracy, but also make sure we're addressing them quickly and through the right workflows. Okay? 

14:47 | Paige
Okay. That makes sense. So, I think, kind of I'll give you a long term and maybe more costly route would be to build out some sort of integration with those tools where Autumn, that would then be able to, execute workflows based on the type of ticket that's submitted. So, if it's a, incorrect item and there's a swap needed, Adam could potentially help to execute on that or, you know, if it's something that just needs to be returned, cause it was overshipped, could execute on, you know, sending shipping labels, or if something was under shipped, maybe do that as well. So those are, those would be the options that would require for all of those systems to have apis in place that would allow us to integrate with those tools. But that would be the potential the other option would be to keep that portion still, part of the human element. 

15:50 | Valerie
For. 

15:51 | Paige
there to at least be, some, we call it a service catalog, and all of the items within the service catalog would be service requests. So, a service request might look like, wrong product, or, you know, additional product ship or missing product. And so, those might be the three options within the, CPG portion of the catalog. And then folks would select the proper one. Adam would actually help them to fill out the form based on the conversation had prior, and then that would be submitted as a ticket into the system for, a human on the other side to actually action that within the, these other tools, that would have no, no, additional cost, but you would still have that, the human element in there. If you were looking to fully automate that, that's something that we could do dependent on the, the availability of the apis. Does that sound, either one like, or I guess you have a preference between the two, as far as what you'd like to have this look like today? 

17:03 | Valerie
I would say today, it probably will require a hybrid approach. We will need the human element, while the seed to sale systems are… improving, I would say, just to give you an example, one of the challenges we have today, the API is available and we are able to read the API data, but being able to write into their system is a challenge. 

17:36 | Paige
Got it. 

17:37 | Valerie
Okay. And so that's where the human component will continue to be necessary, 

17:45 | Valerie
Not to say that we wouldn't want the human component anyway. We've believed, I know crazy talk, but sometimes stores say that they're missing stuff, and then an hour later they find those things. So, I would say that, the human element will probably continue to be a portion, for a while. Yeah, but short… version, hybrid approach. 

18:10 | Paige
Okay. That's great. And, you know, it could even be potentially like, you know, an option could be that if the apis, if they have great read apis, that we could pull that information into, you know, wherever, and have that easily accessible. So that, you know, maybe save a click here and there, but that, the final action is still taken by a human, which I completely understand, especially with, you know, errors and mistakes and whatever else that might be made when you're thinking you're missing something. So, that absolutely makes sense. Just know that, yeah, absolutely can be done. And I think for the, you know, the main purpose of having, logs and history and data behind the asks and ensuring that these things are being taken care of in a timely manner. Atomicwork could be a good fit. You know, I would obviously love for you to see what the tool looks like with all of this in mind, and to really, you know, decide if that's, if it's something that you'd like to look into further, but, you know, for the idea of at the very front end having self help, and then potentially turning that into, help from someone on the other side within these teams, it could actually work quite well, which, you know, I think, yeah, I would love for you to see. 

19:45 | Valerie
Yeah, I think that could be interesting because even… if Adam was not able to write into the system, what I could do is potentially leverage Adam to say this is what broke. All right here's, the ticket and these are all the actions you need to perform, please confirm you've performed these actions. And then, and then I can show that the ticket has completed, right? So now, I can use Adam to help force following the workflows. 

20:20 | Paige
Yep. Yeah, absolutely. And that's, that's one other area that, we would be able to show would be this idea that we call a Genesis. So you can just think of it as backend help, where, Adam is providing. Hey, here's, what it looks like, you know, here's. Here's, the issue that's being described by the employee or the end user. And here are all of the steps that Adam has learned from, whether it be your, you know, your documentation or wherever, or the historical tickets. Here are the steps that would need to be taken in order to resolve this. And providing that right within the ticket so that, you know, they can make sure, to follow those, I think would potentially be helpful. And it's a growing, that portion of the system is growing as well and we can talk about this further. But, into an area where the agent can then, you know, ask, continue to ask Adam for assistance within the ticket if needed. Today, it's a little bit more static but, that's where we're headed. So, yeah, I think it could, it could be a good fit. I would love to have some more examples of others. So obviously, there's that one as being a primary example. But, would you be able to provide some additional examples of where maybe, a ticket for accounting and finance, or where a ticket for sales might come in? 

21:50 | Valerie
Yes. So, let's stick with the, shipment example where something went wrong during the shipment. The… CPG component is that team will need to determine if they need to physically go back to pick up products or not they'll need to validate whether or not they have to, or whether or not they should virtually adjust the manifest or create a new manifest. And then once those transactions are done confirmed and executed, they impact the revenue. So, the invoicing… team will need to be notified of the downstream impacts so that they can make changes to the invoices. Whether that be pricing quantity or in some cases, a whole new invoice, or even a credit memo could be necessary depending on the transaction type. And then the third component would be on the sales side. So the, whenever there is a delivery error, it impacts our revenue. So, their goals for the month may have been impacted, whether or not they're on track or off track, communication with the customer may be necessary, if this is a repeat error to help understand why we're having this error and, whether that's something gti needs to address on their side, or if that's something that we've had a miscommunication with the store and the store said, yes, please deliver. And we've shown up at their doorstep and they're like, psych, we don't want delivery today, right? Yeah. So that's where our sales team would get involved. And then I would say there's the quiet force which would be ultimately the customer. So, you know, the customer, experience is what gets sales going round and round. So, if the customer isn't getting a smooth delivery, if we are shipping incorrect items, that is not the best customer experience. And so, we'd want to notify… sales so that they can figure out the best way to, manage that relationship appropriately with their customer. 

24:19 | Paige
Okay. That makes sense. And hearing, that all three teams could be involved within a single instance of, or a single challenge, there's some great ways that we can, accomplish that with making sure that all of the teams are doing their part, for the end result of, a resolution. So yeah, that absolutely makes sense. That's, that's a great example. 

24:50 | Valerie
I think to me that's where Adam could be beneficial because sometimes the, excuse me, sometimes the sales team may be able to notify us of a pricing change which might not have a direct impact on the CPG team, but it will on the finance team that's doing the invoicing at that moment. And so, Adam can help us with a little of that, I'm going to call it ticket management, right? So, this change has occurred, these are all the activities that are now impacted. And now we can direct here all the actions that need to happen because this activity changed. 

25:32 | Paige
Yeah, yep, absolutely. So, yeah, I think, that's a, it's a great call out. And, I do feel like, there is the potential that this could, it could be a good fit. Talk to me about a little bit about, your process as it relates to looking at different tools and, making sure that, you know, the proper teams are looped in, what does that look like for you all internally?

Great question. Are you talking current state or are you speaking to future state,

Talking about, as it relates to probably this evaluation specifically, what, what needs to happen to make sure that, I suppose by the end of the evaluation, you are confident, in the tool that you're choosing. And, the teams that are impacted are also confident in that decision.

Understood. So, step one, a little general footwork, right? Who's out there? What are the tools? What, what are the basic requirements in order to frame up, an initial version, to see if adding this software, does, give us higher visibility and ultimately, does it result in less work? Because if it ends up, where we end up having to click four times, five times, 10 times more in order to achieve the same results, then this isn't the right path. Yeah, I think the second piece would be, after that initial footwork is complete. It's, filling out an NDA, giving that, partner… or potential partner, some more information about our business and getting the it team involved to make sure that, the… information security rules and regulations that we have at gti, are compatible with those of the software. I'm, interested in working with, based on those and making sure the API connections are something that the, company can work with, then I would say the next steps… excuse me, I would say the next steps from there, would be working with my business partners. So, seeing… a light demonstration of what the tool could do with maybe some test data or sample data, understanding a little more about what does that roadmap look like? What is the work we have to do on the front end? So that this tool is more than just an extra paperweight on the back end once we're done with it. So knowing all that to be true, knowing that we're headed into the last quarter of the year, my guess is that we're probably looking, at the soonest of 20 26 solution, but I do expect to start having a list of, software that I think could be compatible as well as of those softwares that are compatible. What does the roadmap look like? And what does the onboarding look like in order to make it a potential success story for both of us, both gti, and in this case, atomicwork? 

29:18 | Paige
Yep. Okay. That makes sense. And that's really helpful to know, you know, I just want to make sure that, I'm providing you with enough support as you're going through, but not coming across as pushy or, you know, as a pest. So, really helpful to know. And I can, it sounds like, maybe, you know, if you want to take back our conversation, I can send over some information for you. It sounds like next step might be, getting an NDA in place prior to a demo, is that correct? 

29:55 | Valerie
Yeah, I would like to get an NDA into place, to follow our workflow. And then that way, as… you ask more questions and get to know our business more, we're.

we're covered. Well, that sounds great. Well, we have one that I can send over to you or if you have one that you use, we can also, I can submit that to legal. So, whichever way you'd like to do, I'm happy to follow that.

I'll get one from my infosec team and send it your way. My guess is, in the last one, we did, different software, different program completely. They were, asking for the NDA of that third party software. So, my guess is that we're going to want to switch… you know, I'll show you my NDA if you show me yours type conversation, yeah? 

30:52 | Paige
Okay, deal. Well, then I will send you the link to ours, right after the call here, so that you've got it when they ask for it. And then I'll keep an eye out, for yours, and we can figure out which path we want to go down. Great. There, we can, see what this looks like as far as, getting it involved potentially. But, you just let me know what you need, to make this a little bit easier. But, in addition to the NDA, I'll send over, some additional information so that you've got, everything that well, hopefully, you know, most of what you need at the beginning here. 

31:26 | Valerie
Yeah, I think with the NDA and then in general, if you've got something that says, based on the partners we've worked with, typically, these are like the two or three systems… whatever they might be. So, we found that it works well if you've got a system for accounting or a system for HR or a system for, and… then, some of the logic that you found has been most successful, that could onboard quickly. From there, I can then understand who I need to bring into my next discussions. And, yeah, we can go from there. 

32:08 | Paige
Okay, deal. That sounds really good. While you mentioned it, just a quick last question. Who do you use for your HRIS… I'm clear? Okay, you don't have a, I.

think lattice might be the answer that you're looking for? 

32:26 | Paige
Okay. Yes, lattice would potentially. Okay. And more like, your internal, like employee database. Do you know where that would, that could be? Lattice, for sure, it could be lattice, or maybe like where you get paychecks from? 

32:43 | Valerie
Work. W, URK? Yep. Okay. 

32:47 | Paige
Familiar. Cool. Okay. That's helpful. Thank you. Okay. I think this is all, we're in a good spot. I know we're a few minutes over here, so, I apologize for, for taking us over, but thank you so much for all of the information. And, I'll send you a quick email here, and then you just let me know what you need, as we're going through this.

Thanks Paige. I appreciate your time today. Thanks.

Valerie. We'll talk to you soon.

Bye bye.
